On the behalf of < blank >. Who shares my steam library.

This is their experience of the game.

Okami truly is a gem in the gaming industry's dust.

I have to say this game is evocative of the older generation of action games. It contains its share of tricky challenges as well  as the distinct way in which the plot unravels. But it wouldn't pique my interest had the atmosphere not been as warm and soulful. 

Okami is a contrast of humour and tragedy, folk and modern as well as a harmonious combination of action and adventure. Throughout the game I experienced heartfelt sorrow and joy, tender emotions brought about by Ammy's dorkiness, irritation at my own ineptitude as a god doge and so on and so forth.
I knew what was in store for me the moment I heard about Orochi and Amaterasu. Further on in the game there are many more allusions to japanese folklore and religion, such as: [spoiler]The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter, Age of the Gods, Kojiki...[/spoiler]

As for the visual part of the game, it's a cel-shaded one (which in no way detracts from its beauty; on the contrary, it gives the game a unique comic touch along with smoothness). Moreover, it is an HD version, so the quality is further improved. Personally, I have no qualms about the graphics whatsoever. 

I would recommend this game to people who are in for a good adventure game and are good sports about lack of adequate voiceover; it suits casuals (dw, it's not Dark Souls) and completionists (<-tons of collectibles~).

[h1]Okami HD Review[/h1]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is brilliant, I can't go into lots of detail because I do not want to spoil anything and I haven't finished the game *yet*.
Basically, you play as Amaterasu, a wolf god thingy that has the power of the brush, with this brush you can slice monsters, restore objects and more.

[h1]Controlls[/h1]
The controls are great, I hadn't expected controls this good from a DS port. The camera is a bit annoying but other than that, they're good.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
In this game, you have the power of the brush, this means you can hold ctrl and paint your world! Bob ross simulator! It's not that free but you can (as far as I know): Restore broken objects, slice things (like grass, enemies, etc), manipulate celestial stuff and likely more.

[h1]Art[/h1]
The art in this game is amazing, it uses the ink border style as well as everything in general looking like paint. The borders for things are kinda like Borderlands, except a bit more obvious ;P

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
Alt tab bug like Skyrim, you alt tab and *sometimes* it bugs out and displays your windows cursor.
That's all I know in the bugs section.

[h1]Overall:[/h1]
Story - 10/10
Art - 10/10
Controls - 8/10
Mechanics - 9/10

Average Score: 9.25/10
I recommend this game :P

Okami hat fantastisch! Es ist ein fantastisches Action-Adventure nach Art der The Legend of Zelda-Reihe, jedoch mit vielen eigenen Ideen. Der Stil ist einzigartig und die Mechanik mit den Göttlichen Pinseltechniken, die Umgebung zu beeinflussen ist genial. Die Story ist auch ein großer Pluspunkt, denn die Abenteuer der Göttin Amaterasu sind lang und voller interessanter Twists. Gerade wenn man denkt, es sei vorbei, öffnet sich ein neues Gebiet mit einer neuen riesigen Questline und weiteren interessanten Charakteren mit eigenen Geschichten und Nebenquests. Musikalisch ist Okami ein Traum. Die Tracks sind toll und gerade der Song, wenn man einen Wächtersprössling erweckt verschafft einem Gänsehaut. Einfach - man verzeih den Wortwitz - göttlich!
Jedoch ist es kein perfektes Spiel: Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist in meinen Augen zu niedrig, die Dungeons - ein weiteres Element, dass direkt der The Legend of Zelda-Reihe entnommen scheint - sind zu kurz und die darin enthaltenen Rätsel wieder viel zu simpel. Zumindest designtechnisch wissen sie zu begeistern.
Ein paar letzte Sätze seien an die HD-Version gerichtet. Technisch habe ich wenig zu bemängeln. Es sieht dank des kaum alternden Stils einfach toll aus und die Framerate ist absolut stabil. Jedoch hätte man noch ein paar Schreiben drehen können. Dass Personen und Tiere erst (unübertrieben) 10m von einem entfernt und zerstörbare Gegenstände wie Bäume rund 20m entfernt aufploppen (und dass IMMER, nicht nur ab und zu), darf im Jahr 2017 nicht mehr sein. Und auch die Ladezeiten sind für einen solch alten und resourcenschonenden Titel zu lang.
Trotzdem ein Titel, den ich absolut empfehlen kann.

39403223.review:
It's really hard to not draw comparisons to Zelda, but it's pretty much a Zelda like game with a Japanese mythology backdrop

Overall, a casual playthrough is enjoyable, though sometimes the game doesn't make itself too clear with what it wants or expects of you.  Exploration is rewarding, but honestly your first time through will feel a little overwhelming in terms of abilities you get late game that opens up areas as far back as the very beginning of the game.

Combat, when it happens, is either too easy or too demanding where again, the game doesn't always do a good job with telling you what it expects.  It will painstakingly hold your hand with the first couple of enemy types, but then other times completely forgo any explanation in a game where you have half a dozen combat options and only one or two work with certain enemies.  Combat also doesn't vary itself often.  While there's technically maybe over 30 kinds of enemies, there's maybe only 10 with some variation of looks, health, and slight tweaks to behavior.  The basic enemy you encounter the first time and the few after that basically serve as the templates for what you'll encounter the rest of the game.  There's something to be said about the main mechanic of the game, the brush techniques, breaking up the pace of combat, though personally I found it had it's own sort of flow though at times felt too much like micromanaging myself.  Really the only complaint I'd have here is with enemies having a certain weakness, you need a source of that weakness somewhere within the battle zone or figure out some of the secret and costly techniques.

Speaking of which, you can upgrade some of your techniques..... and it really doesn't feel like doing so has much impact on what you can or can't do sadly.  Finding the secret techniques is also a little lackluster, or often too little too late.  Really the one positive I can say is that there is a bomb ability and later just being able to have the ability to place more than one helps make up for the fact that placing them can be finicky between the camera and where you draw them.

Environments are pretty cool, though I think as the game goes on the design of them gets progressively weaker.

This technically being my second playthrough with my first on the Wii, I can also say that playing this game on a controller, while lacking the novelty of the motion controls, felt better overall and that I had a lot more control over what I was doing.

100%ing this game is also not the greatest.  While the in-game consideration for 100% is forgiving, there's certain sections of the game that leave something to be desired.  Collecting all of the 100 (99) beads is tedious without some sort of guide as there's just some activities and side quests you'd probably never notice without meticulously talking to every NPC, and even then I recall a few of them where if I didn't use a guide I would've never figured it out on my own.  Treasure hunting feels much more like a chore than anything rewarding.  Earning the quivalent of experience breaks up the game when interacting with the animals found throughout the game.  There's some stupidly missable enemies that you can only ever encounter once without a second playthrough to fill out the beastiary, and feeding all of the animals on the map is not only tedious but doesn't really reward you with anything neither.  Don't even get me started on the fish tome, which isn't the worst grind I've experienced in a game but it certainly is a task with no real in-game reward either.

Game certainly has additional playthroughs in mind.  Not that those playthroughs have any additional content to offer, but it allows for you to really kind of take in the game a bit more.  Find what you might've missed the first time without having to go all the way back to a previous save.  You'll still have much of the same progress you had from the previous game with all of your upgrades, though you'll need to find much of the same items all over again.  If you do complete the game in certain categories, you'll be rewarded with the ability to change your appearence cosmetically, so if the 100% is on something other than your first playthrough you don't need to be bored by the same visuals.  I won't spoil what you get for collecting all of the beads, but it's a reward that is worth the trouble you would've put into getting them all.  All of that said though, I would've prefered being able to change my appearence while going through the game normally, and the ultimate reward is really only something you'd really get to experience only if you REALLY like to play this game.  I realize the original release was on the PS2 and these were the limitations of the time, as well as the usual designs, but I really wouldn't recommend 100%ing the game unless if you're really enjoying yourself with it, much less a second playthrough since there really isn't much to offer outside of your first.

Overall though, the game is fun and would be something I'd recommend to people.  It's relatively accessible.  It looks pretty.  Characters are interesting enough.  Game does engage you enough for it to not be a bore.  If you like adventure games or Zelda, this game is up your ally.

This port doesn't suffer from any performance issues that the game didn't originally have neither, which is more of a positive as far as ports go.

8/10, glad this game still is made available to people years after the original release

I first played this on the PS2 and can't quite remember how many times I played it through in NG+ mode. I've waited such a long time for this to be remastered on PC and am glad that all other platforms get to experience it now as well.

I have no idea how to describe this game but I can agree with some other reviews that this is a hilarious take on Japanese mythology. You obviously play as a wolf but you've been inhabited by the Japanese sun goddess Amaterasu. I don't want to spoil the story any but you basically fight off demons and monsters to save villages and befriend villagers. Your ultimate goal is to undo the damage caused by evil and restore their world.

As Amaterasu your abilities in and out of combat will vary, you can generally always use the celestial brush but weapons are combat specific. The brush is a utility out of combat with more combinations than I'd prefer to list, and it's a weapon in combat to be used alongside your main weapons.

The environments are vast and beautifully designed considering the age of this game. The villagers and entities within them have a lot of depth to their characters with most having a considerable amount of dialogue. I find it comical how only some can see your true form and everyone else just sees some random wolf, it can lead to some great conversations. On that topic nobody in this game actually speaks words, they only mumble or mutter, so the entire game is subtitled no matter what.

I do have some gripes though:
-Related to the conversations themselves, some of the dialogue comes on a bit strong with the self-discipline and strive for perfection in whatever it is they're doing. It's not bad but I feel it takes away from your own story, it's distracting.
-The transitions can get annoying, between areas, day/night cycle, feeding the animals, and every single item you pick up. I understand the loading screens between areas as it was a PS2 game originally. But why was there a paused transition for the day/night cycle, interrupting you every time? Feeding an animal will also cause it to load a little scene where you... feed an animal... every single time. The item pickups really didn't need this either, pausing the action and giving me two panels of descriptions on what the item is and what it does. At 30 hours in, pretty sure I know what the bones do.

Those gripes are minor though and aren't going to destroy the story or gameplay for you. Seriously watch the trailers, read and watch reviews, as the descriptions will only go so far for this game.

39313047.review:
[h1][b]¿Qué es Okami HD?[/b][/h1]

Okami HD es la remasterización del titulo que apareció en PS2 durante el 2006, desarrollado por el difundo estudio Clover, con mejoras gráficas y soporte de resoluciones 4K, en el caso de PC. El titulo nos pone en el lugar de Amaterasu (en forma de un lobo blanco), la diosa del Sol en la mitología japonesa, quien debe enfrentarse a la serpiente de ocho cabezas, Orochi, quien esta azotando las tierras de Nipón en su regreso tras 100 años de ser derrotado por nuestra protagonista.

[b]LO BUENO[/b]

* Dirección artística única que hasta el dia de hoy sigue manteniéndose fuerte
* El soundtrack maravilloso que evoca el folclore japones
* Lo mas cercano a un juego tipo The Legend of Zelda que vas a encontrar
* La mecánica de los pinceles celestiales

[b]LO MALO[/b]

* 30 FPS (debido a aspecto técnicos del engine del juego)
* Varias mecánicas jugables como de diseño anacrónico
* El combate, el punto flojo del juego

[b]Lo que me dejó...[/b]

Pasaron 9 años. 9 años donde pude tener mi PS2 y probar, lo que seria, uno de los juegos que mas me ha impactado en mi adolescencia. Una aventura que recuerdo que el mismo lo daba como el gran final. La meta estaba ahí, frente a mis ojos, pero no quería que terminara. No quería que se terminara esta hermosa aventura. Pero para mi sorpresa, el juego siguió, Y UN BUEN RATO!. Esa experiencia de desear que esto no se terminara, se cumplió, pero como todo tiene un final, no pude estar mas contento con el viaje y las memorias que me ha dejado.

Okami para mi gusto es una joya. Un diamante en bruto que Capcom nunca tuvo intenciones de pulir apropiadamente, viéndose reflejado en las pobres ventas de PS2 y Wii. Jamas fue un titulo, digamos, que le diera mucho prestigio a la empresa, pero si por el boca a boca de la gente que realmente amó hasta el hartazgo este juego, lo que también daría el batacazo del mejor estudio creativo que tuvo Capcom en su época.

Mas allá de que tenga una relación de amor-odio con Capcom (y también mas de uno o millones sientan lo mismo) tengo que decir GRACIAS!. Gracias por traer a Ammy e Issun a Steam. Siempre pedí, desde el fondo de mi corazón que saliese para la plataforma PC. Siempre. Vaya a saber por que divina intervención haya pasado por Capcom, pero esta fue una de mis grandes sorpresas del 2017 y nunca estuve mas contento de volver a jugar Okami. De volver a sentirme nostálgico, reírme con sus personajes e historias, llorar cuando las emociones estaban a flor de piel, de perder horas y horas y escuchar su hermoso soundtrack.

Mas allá de los aspectos técnicos y problemas que se presentan por ser un juego de hace dos generaciones atrás, el port a PC es “correcto”. No es un juego que demande demasiado también aunque no podría imaginarme esta maravilla corriendo en 60 FPS. Otras como el sistema de salvado y el plataformeo pueden llegar a parecer muy viejos.

No lo se. Para mi Okami es y sera una obra de mucho amor que habla de sus desarrolladores y que, pese a lo que es, Hideki Kamiya es un loco genio. Un director que pocos entenderán, pero que sus juegos están llenos de potencial.

Originalmente iba a hablar un poco de como es que Okami cuenta ciertos relatos mitológicos como el de Susano y Yamata-no-Orochi y el papel que cumplió Amaterasu (que si vamos al caso toda la premisa del juego es basicamente dicho relato) pero termino siendo un poco de como es que Okami es parte de lo que soy como jugador hoy en día y todo lo que representa en mi vida.

Okami es un juegazo y pasado ya 11 años, sigue demostrando que puede aullar como todo un lobo alfa.

En pocas palabras, mi primer gran amor con un videojuego.

《大神》——被誉为生不逢时的佳作实际上被其落后的游戏设计拖了后腿。

①剧情：这作的卖点可能就是诸多评论里所探讨的日本神话世界观，不然各位也不用篇篇拿到第一个来说了。

剧情开场并没有什么新意，俗套的世界出现危机，英雄拯救世界类型，这一点其实也不是不行，俗套意味着剧情崩坏的风险会大幅降低，不会影响后期的剧情体验。

1：所有美术素材放弃刻画，全部采取厚涂概括！（会使玩家对于画面的注意力集中程度大幅降低）
2：没有远景细节的渲染！基本上都是一个底色渐变来概括时间变化。（不给予玩家通过场景放松精神的机会，正面例子请参考刺客信条的鸟瞰视角）
3：宣传中的2k4k画面提升与时代脱节（美术风格拖后腿）

令人窒息的30帧与画面动态模糊的无敌组合！！！（没有帧数提升就算了，还会动态模糊！画面晕乎乎的再一次降低了玩家的专注力）

④：游戏设计：与时代脱节的游戏设计。
冗长且糟糕的新手教学（看到评测区有人就被这一点劝退了233）
过于强调解谜与战斗的结合（再一次分散玩家注意力）
游戏演出与剧情事件的比例不均匀（第一次去找伊邪，在那个地方来来回回绕圈跑了几次？）

ps:一个优秀的游戏教学应该是玩家在通过关卡的同时自然而然地就学会了。所谓谜题逻辑自治，优秀例子从马里奥系列再到现在的独立游戏inside都能体现出来。

总评：
一个游戏体验不佳的日本古风解谜动作游戏。
5/10
不推荐新玩家购买。
最近玩日本神话文化类的不如加150玩《仁王》。
如果觉得《仁王》文化气息不足可以去玩《Tsukumogami》。
有情怀的老玩家请不用在意评分，此评分仅供新玩家购买参考。

原文地址[url=https://steamcn.com/t346911-1-1]《大神绝景版》水墨画卷中的济世物语[/url][/quote]
　　卡普空的《大神绝景版》已于2017年12月13日在PC平台发售，而PS4版以及X1版也于12月21日，大神绝景版实际上是对2006年PS2上的初代大神的冷饭，此次卡表对PS3高清版的画面进行重置，加强了角色背景的贴图画质，将支持4K分辨率画面（不过我的电脑也只有1080p），可以说是很良心了。
　　虽然网上很多人说这是一款“冷门神作”，不过我个人并没有觉得有多冷门，我也是很早就接触到了大神这款游戏，并且印象中当年对大神的报道无论是在网络上还是在一些游戏机杂志上都是有介绍的。
　　《大神》的故事源于日本神话，而游戏中的许多内容，都和东方文化有着密不可分的联系，如果你是个日本文化的爱好者，一定能从中发现你熟悉的日本元素。作为一款动作类角色扮演游戏，大神以水墨画的风格来展现出游戏中的风景、NPC、道具，同时也提升了游戏的艺术水平。故事从伊耶那岐(イザナギ)和白野威(しらぬい。全盛期的天照大神)协力封印八岐大蛇(ヤマタノオロチ)百年之后，一位作死的NPC解除了封印，导致ヤマタノオロチ复苏，为世界带来灾难，世界陷入了黑暗，这时玩家需要扮演一只“狼”，也就是我们的“小神”白野威，踏上复苏大地的济世之旅。
　　对于有一定日语基础的玩家而言，看到标题“大神”和游戏中玩家所扮演的白野威，大致就能猜到游戏作者的用意所在了，日文中“狼(おおかみ)”和大神(おおかみ)的假名书写方式是一致的，也许这样算“玩梗”，不过具体日本神话中是否有狗形象的白野威，因为最近比较忙，就没有什么时间去考据了。不过游戏对于大神的写法又有两种，一种是称呼白野威和天照时的“题“大神”和游戏中玩家所扮演的白野威，大致就能猜到游戏作者的用意所在了，日文中“おおかみ”另一种是咲耶小姐称呼天照时候的“おおみかみアマテラス”写作“大御神天照”。
　　卡表炒冷饭也不是一天两天的事了，作为一个玩家，总体而言还是挺满意的，虽然嘴上说着不要，钱包还是很诚实的（虽然龙之信条的重制版我觉得也不是很高清）。由于我时间限制，也没有去查各个作品重制版的销量情况。不过我认为，重制版可以有，对于那些经典的作品，不过重置频率不要太高就好。当然开发商怎么想那是他们的事情了……
　　《大神》的PC重制版我还是十分推荐的，因为他支持键鼠操作……要知道，这游戏的笔调功能，用键鼠可是比用手柄方便多了，玩起来也感觉十分爽快。虽然键位比如F1和backspace我玩其他游戏并不常用，不过游玩过一定时间之后，习惯了之后，觉得一点也不影响。至于这次大神的重制版只有日文英文，虽然我没去找汉化补丁，不过粗翻版的应该还是有的吧，我个人认为大神这样一款游戏，汉化补丁或者官方汉化还是需要的，因为游戏中的对话给了很多提示，而且以神话背景为载体的游戏，剧情对话还是十分重要的。前一段时间卡表的《龙之信条黑暗觉醒》更新了官方中文，我还是很高兴的，希望有朝一日卡表心情好了也把大神的简体中文更新了。
　　另外这次重制版的大神有滤镜，可能会在“全局视角“的情况下，或者快速奔跑的情况下产生不适，在标题菜单的设置里把滤镜调到最低即可。当然我个人还是推荐用狗的”第三人称“视角游玩比较好。
　　不过键鼠也有键鼠的弊端（？）就是全屏状态下虽然玩起来很爽，但是不能像手柄那样距离屏幕很远地游玩，毕竟是不可兼得的事情，也没有什么太大的损失。

39153050.review:
Você joga como Amaterasu na forma de um lobo e um artista viajante, Issun. A premissa do jogo é simples: restaurar a terra de Nippon que está sob uma maldição utilizando os poderes dos outros treze deuses do zodiaco e representando-os por meio de desenhos. Sim, o grande diferencial na jogabilidade de Okami é a intereção com o mapa, inimigos e personagens em geral por meio de desenhos. Tudo isso poderia ter sido simplificado com menus ou combos com os botões, ao invés disso, você tem que utilizar o pincel, você tem que interagir diretamente com o jogo e isso desperta um sentimento de importância. O cenário muda, os personagens ficam felizes ou tristes com os acontecimentos. Cada poder tem uma interação diferente em combate.

Lembro de ter jogado primeiro no PS2 e me surpreendi com a capacidade do jogo em entender o que eu estava tentando fazer mesmo apresentando garranchos de uma criança analfabeta.

A única crítica negativa desse lançamento para PC é que não há uma tradução para o português. É de fundamental importância para o jogo a leitura e a interação com os personagens, não é um jogo que se pode simplesmente fazer a história principal e acabou. Dificilmente você vai conseguir fazer isso, vai querer mais, saber mais, resolver todos os problemas, encontrar todos os tesouros.
Originalmente o jogo foi desenvolvido para o público oriental e, mesmo na época do PS2, não teve um sucesso de vendas no ocidente. Com a Capcom tomando a frente desse título nas terras do Tio Sam, esperava um trabalho melhor na linguagem. 

Um ponto muito forte do game é que, se comparado com outros títulos de peso, Okami entrega muito conteúdo por um preço baixo. Vale o investimento e o retorno é uma experiência única.

39152625.review:
How to start praising this game? I don't know but I'll try.

In Okami, you play as Amaterasu, the Shinto goddess of sun manifesting herself in the form of a white wolf. All along, a sprite named Issun accompanies you and becomes your voice. As your celestial form isn't openly visible to humans, they keep mistaking you for a random mutt. But you learn to live with that after a while.

You delve into a beautifully crafted world. And honestly, words fail to shine even a tiny bit of light on how spectacular the art in this game is. I could just rant on and on about it without ever getting tired. The visuals alone can easily captivate you for hours on end. 

So throughout your journey, you learn new brush techniques. You can pause the game at will by pressing Ctrl and draw the symbols you have learnt to pull awesome tricks. Cut a baddie, a solid rock or even a whole bunch of trees in half in one invisible slash? The celestial brush got you covered. You want to start a fire, make it rain for real, start a galestorm or bring down a heavenly thunderbolt on thy enemies? Easy peasy fam! 

You obtain these techniques gradually and they allow you to access new stuff and areas in a Zelda-like fashion. Though I really don't like the comparison, because Okami is by all means its own masterpiece of a game. 

The story is all you would expect from a narrative of ancient Japanese myth. While it may not be all magically new or refreshing, it is just enough to be relevant. Not to mention the constant slapstick humor. The story is never presented in an overly serious manner. You are always given your moments of giggly fun. I don't know, you should just try "golden fury" and "brown rage" on mythical demons to taste a piece of it for yourself.

All in all the only things some PC players (especially newer-gen players) will dislike are the occasional unskippable dialogues and the presence of brief loading screens when transitioning between each individual area. But this game bears the soul of a now-dead era of gaming. So if you are familiar with and miss those times, I don't think you'll be bothered by it. 

Oh, there is also the PS2 legacy of locked 30 fps. But come on, are you really going to dwell on that? 

The conclusion? 999/10! Would be a sun god and called a mutt anytime again.

喂食路过的小动物，获得他们的爱与支持？抑或你只是发自内心的爱着他们， 想看他们吃东西的可爱样子

A melhor maneira de se aproveitar essa jóia do PS2, esta versão remasterizada está simplesmente linda, platinei o jogo em uma semana seguida de gameplay e posso dizer que vale muito a pena sim. Os gráficos ficaram ainda mais lindo em 1080p, e há também suporte para mouse e teclado para quem quiser.

Recomendo este jogo principalmente para quem for fã de Zelda e procura um título a altura da franquia da Nintendo. Posso dizer tranquilamente como fã de Zelda, que Okami supera fácil alguns dos jogos da série de Link. Os personagens são extremamente carismáticos, o gameplay é imersivo e a história é pra lá de interessante. Você controla Amaterasu, a deusa do Sol que vem para Terra em forma de lobo, afim de restaurar a natureza e acabar com as trevas que tomaram o mundo. O estilo gráfico é simplesmente único, um cellshading usado de uma forma nunca antes vista e nunca mais repetida em nenhum outro título. A sensação é de se estar jogando uma pintura viva.

Sobre a parte técnica, Okami HD roda de maneira perfeita, não presenciei nenhuma queda bruta de frames durante minha jogatina. Única coisa que pra mim deixou a desejar foi o draw distance que continua praticamente idêntico a versão original, com alguns objetos só surgindo quando se está realmente próximo deles. Não é algo que chega a atrapalhar a experiência, visto que ele foi pensado para ser assim lá em 2006. 
Um único pequeno detalhe que me deixou realmente triste foi o fato de terem trocado a música dos créditos, não sei se foi por algum motivo de direitos autorais, só sei que ela realmente fez, para mim, uma falta danada na conclusão do jogo.

E é isso, pra quem nunca jogou,  faça favor a si mesmo e jogue esta obra prima. E pra quem já jogou, este é um jogo que sempre vale a pena ser revisto.

        06年在PS2上我就通关了，在游戏厅用自己记忆卡玩的。那时还没有白金奖杯，也没有中文翻译，现在回头看看，当年我只有大海无鱼没有完成，近乎白金。但只靠着画面去想象的剧情也让我感动不已，至今记得真正的一周目结尾，在BGM：太阳升 的伴奏下我一边哭一边暴打最终BOSS，甚至为了多打它一会，用攻击弱的武器打。当真傻得不行。
       最后说一下为什么要写这些东西，实际上上面写的东西没有达到我写评测的目的，但这次游戏通关后，一寸对我说：“这就是天照大神的故事与旅程。作为陪伴天公旅行的我天道太子一寸将这段故事画与你看，说与你听。你会吧这个故事说给别人吗？”
        当时没有中文，我不知道一寸最后说的话，现在的我文笔也无法描述天照大神的故事是多么感动人心。所以我写下这点东西，就是想说，去看一下吧，四叶草的绝响， 白狼 白野威 大神天照 它的见闻，它的旅途，它的故事，它的传奇。
（PS：神之手虽然好玩但真的是半成品，四叶草恐怖如斯。）

39197064.review:
Nakatsukuni halkı, tanrılara olan inançlarını artık büyük ölçüde kaybetmiş, gündelik hayatın stresi içinde yaşayıp gitmektedirler. Günün birinde, tanrıları ve tanrılara ait hikayeleri saçmalık olarak nitelendiren adamın biri, Shiranui ve Izanagi’ye ait efsanenin gerçekliğinden şüphe ederek Izayoi Mabedi’ne gider ve Yamata no Orochi’yi oraya mühürleyen Tsukuyomi kılıcını yerinden çıkarır. Adamın bunu yapmasıyla birlikte, yüz yıldır oraya hapsolmuş Orochi’nin ruhu yeniden dünyaya gelir ve Nakatsukuni ülkesini karanlıklara gömen bir lanete sebebiyet verir. Durumun vehametinin farkına varan Kamiki Köyü’nün koruyucu ağaç ruhu Sakuya, Shiranui heykelinin önünde yüce güneş tanrıçası Amaterasu‘ya dünyayı aydınlatıp kendilerini kurtarması için dua eder, akabinde tanrıça Amaterasu beyaz bir kurt şeklinde reenkarne olarak dünyaya gelir ve maceramız burada başlar.

Oynanışa gelirsek, The Legend of Zelda oyunlarına aşina olanların yabancılık çekmeyeceği tarz bir oynanışa sahip; bir seviye atlama sisteminin olmaması, renkli NPC’ler ve onlar için yaptığımız ufak yan görevler, farklı özelliklere sahip farklı eşyalar, sağdan soldan bulduğumuz sandıklardan çıkan toplanabilirler, bulmacalarla dolu zindanlar, bölüm sonu canavarları ve benzeri öğeler son derece Zeldavari. Bunda yönetmen Kamiya Hideki’nin bir Zelda hayranı olmasının etkisi elbette bulunmakla birlikte, aramızdaki cahil arkadaşların  “bu bildiğin Twilight Princess’ın çakması yea, lanet manet kurt murt aynı” diye sazanlama atlamadan önce naçizane bir şekilde iki oyunun çıkış tarihlerine bir göz atmalarını öneriyorum. Oyun açık dünya bir haritaya sahip olsa da, yeni nesil açık dünya oyunlarının aksine başladığımız andan itibaren tüm haritayı ulaşılabilir bir şekilde ayağımızın altına sermiyor. Haritada yeni bir bölgeye ulaşmak için, ya mevcut bulunduğumuz bölgedeki bölüm sonu canavarını yenip anahtar görevindeki gerekli bir eşyayı ele geçirmemiz gerekiyor, ya da birazdan değineceğim fırça tekniklerini öğrenip gereken yerde kullanmamız. Açık dünya, zindanlar, bulmacalar falan filan iyi hoş da, Orochi’nin lanetiyle karanlığa gömülmüş bu dünyada düşmanlarımız yok mu? Tabii ki var. (Keşke şu cümleyi bölüm sonu canavarlarından bahsetmeden önce yazsaydım.) Amanojaku, Tengu, Ubume, Oni, Namahage gibi Japon kültürüne ait yōkai ve diğer yaratıklar Ōkami’deki başlıca düşmanlarımız.

Oyun, hack ‘n’ slash oyunları ile ünlü Kamiya Hideki’nin yüzünü kızartmayacak kadar başarılı bir savaş sistemine sahip. Savaşacağımız zaman, klasik JRPG oyunlarından alışık olduğumuz, oyunun “gezinme” dünyasından ayrı -fakat çok iyi yedirilmiş- ayrı bir ekran devreye giriyor ve düşmanlarımızla karşı bu alanda mücadele ediyoruz. Savaşlarda kullanabileceğimiz üç silah kategorisi bulunuyor: kılıç, ayna ve magatama. Japon imparatorluk hanedanının üç kutsal sembolünden (三種の神器/Sanshu no Jingi) esinlenerek yaratılmış bu silahlar, doğal olarak farklı mekaniklere sahipler. Ayna, ortalama bir hasar ve vuruş mesafesine sahip. Magatama ile düşmanın dibine girmeden uzaktan hasar verebiliyoruz ama ayna ve kılıç kadar fazla can götürmüyor. Kılıç ise tahmin edebileceğiniz üzere vuruş mesafesi en kısa silah olmakla birlikte en fazla hasarı vererek dengeyi sağlıyor. Ana silahımıza ek olarak bir de yardımcı silah atayabiliyoruz. Yardımcı silah olarak kullanıldığı zaman ayna kalkan görevi görerek hasar almamızı engelliyor, magatamayı da adeta bir tabanca gibi kullanıp düşmana uzaktan “mermi” yağdırabiliyoruz. Kılıcın ise ikincil silah olarak ayrı bir özelliği yok, dümdüz vuruyor.

Tabii bu mekaniklerin hiçbiri oyunun satış noktası olan fırça teknikleri kadar ilgi çekici değil. Oyunda ilerledikçe yenileri açılan fırça teknikleri ile rüzgar estirebiliyor, ateş ile suyu kontrol edebiliyor ve hatta gece gündüz döngüsünü değiştirebilip zamana hükmedebiliyoruz. Bu teknikler hem oyundaki çeşitli bulmacaları çözerken hem de savaşlarda en büyük yardımcımız oluyor. Önceden de belirttiğim gibi, bu tekniklerin hepsine ha deyince sahip olamıyoruz ve hikayede ilerledikçe (rastgele değil) karşımıza çıkan takımyıldızları birleştirerek orada hapsolmuş fırça tanrılarını -ki bunlar 12 hayvanlı takvimdeki hayvanlar ve Amaterasu’nun çocukları- kurtarıyor, karşılığında da kurtardığımız tanrının tekniğini öğreniyoruz.

Buna ek olarak üstünkörü bir şekilde teknik özelliklerden de bahsedecek olursak, oyunun grafiklerinin geleneksel Japon çizim sanatlarından sumi-e stilinde olması, günümüzde 3-4 yıllık oyunlar bile çamur gibi görünürken, üzerinden 12 yıl geçmiş olmasına rağmen Ōkami’nin grafiksel açıdan gram yaşlanmamasını sağlamış. Oyunun her sahnesi ekran görüntüsü çekilip çıktısı alınıp duvara asılmalık. Buna karşın oyunda bir seslendirme yok, diyaloglar Animal Crossing hayranlarının alışmış olduğu “cıyaklama” şeklinde. Bunu nasıl tanımlayabilirim bilmiyorum, oynayınca görürsünüz. Bu bir eksi yön mü? Kişiden kişiye değişmekle birlikte benim şahsi kanaatimce alıştıktan sonra hoşa giden bir yönü var. Yine de Issun, Susanō, Ushiwaka gibi sevdiğim Ōkami karakterlerini usta Japon seslendirme sanatçılarının ağzından duymak istemezdim desem yalan olur. 6 CD’den oluşan yaklaşık 180 parçalık ve her biri ayrı bir başyapıt olan müziklerine girmek bile istemiyorum, anlatılmaz yaşanır. (Bir de müzikler hakkında nasıl yorum yapılır onu bilmiyorum ama o ayrı hikaye.)

Peki bu oyunun hiç eksi yönü yok mu?

…

Sanırım hayır.

Ciddi ciddi oturdum 10 dakikadır düşünüyorum, nostalji gözlüklerimi çıkartıp objektif olmaya çalışıyorum ama yok, bulamadım. Başta mekanlar arası birkaç saniyelik de olsa giren yükleme ekranlarını söyleyecektim ama sonra oyunun 12 yıllık bir motorla yapıldığını hatırlayarak bunu öne sürmenin adil olmayacağını düşündüm. Başka da aklıma hiçbir şey gelmedi. Evet sayın okur, bu oyunun bir eksi yönü yok. Ha biraz zorlarsak, belki zaman zaman çok uzayan hatta yeri geldiğinde yaklaşık yarım saat durmaksızın devam edebilen diyalogların bazı oyuncuları sıkabileceğini bir eksi yön olarak düşünebiliriz ama sonuçta bu bir Devil May Cry, bir God of War gibi her saniyesi aksiyon dolu, hikayesinden ziyade oynanışıyla öne çıkan ve bu şekilde bir oyun arayan oyunculara hitap eden bir oyun değil. Hikaye odaklı bir oyunda diyalogların fazla olmasını eksi yön olarak göstermek herhalde bir futbol oyununa araba süremediğimiz için eksi puan vermekle aynı şey olacaktır. Bu yüzden Ōkami’yi kendi kulvarında değerlendiriyorum ve oyuna 10 üzerinden 10 veriyorum.

Velhasıl kelam gerek Japon kültürüne, gerek çıktığı dönemin popüler kültürüne göndermelerle dolu bu sanat eserini hâlâ oynamadıysanız kaybınız çoook büyük diyor ve incelemeyi burada sonlandırıyorum.

Never played the PS-2 original, so unlike a lot of other reviewers I haven't got any nostalgia about this. I've played for around 13 hours and have completed the first part of the game, so I feel now's a good point to leave a review. From what I'm reading I may still have dozens of hours of story left, although unless the game really mixes things up all of a sudden (which I very much doubt), I'm unlikely to persist until the end, as I'm starting to feel like I've probably seen most things it has to offer

First off, be aware this game has some of the most annoying design decisions ever:

1. It basically resents the player actually trying to just play it for any length of time, and constantly interrupts the flow of the game every few minutes with super-patronizing hints, cut-scenes and/or exposition. It starts with a horrible 30 minutes intro and continues the "tell-don't-show" theme throughout. I regularly find myself yelling "Just let me play!" at the monitor when it yet again yanks control away from me for  dialogue, item descriptions, or "Captain Obvious" style objective information / puzzle hints by the sidekick, none of which I ask it for.

2. The game has no difficulty setting, and is basically permanently on "very easy" mode - there is little challenge in even the boss battles. Even though it's innovative, combat can become somewhat repetitive and after a while and I've found myself sometimes even avoiding optional encounters because of this. More than once has the game introduced some new enemy with a bombastic cut-scene, making out they'd be this powerful and challenging super-villain, only for me to quickly defeat them, literally without them even getting one move in.

3. The voice acting consists of the most horrible munbling you can imagine. There is no voice acting, the characters just gurgle and grumble to simulate speaking. This is incredibly grating and even worse when done in a high pitch, like the voice used by your side-kick.

4. Different menus and screens have different keys to navigate. Some insist on you using "Backspace" to exit, some let you use escape, none have mouse support. More than once have I pressed a key for nothing to happen and had to remind myself how to navigate around whatever the affected screen was.

Let's be clear, the above aren't minor issues, they're absolutely infuriating!

So why am I recommending it? Well, Steam only allows "Recommend" and "Don't Recommend", and nothing in between, and as it somehow (just!) manages to come together to be more than the sum of it parts, I decided to Recommend,  as on balance I can't say I've not enjoyed my time with it. It looks lovely, play well with mouse and keyboard, is completely unique and when it doesn't get in the way of itself, fun to play.

39165750.review:
Review: Okami HD - Immer noch ein Meisterwerk? [PC]

Am 12. Dezember 2017 veröffentlichte Capcom das HD-Remake zum Action-Adventure Okami. Doch kann das neue HD-Remake überzeugen? Finden wir es heraus und somit Willkommen zum Test von Okami HD!

Das Action-Adventure wurde schon im Jahr 2006 für die PlayStation 2 veröffentlicht und erschien bis jetzt auch schon fast für jede andere Konsole. Nun aber gibt es Okami auch endlich für den PC als HD-Remake und somit kommen wir nun erst mal zur Geschichte.

Story:
Die Story dürfte zwar schon jeden bekannt sein, trotzdem hier eine kleine Zusammenfassung. In Okami spielen wir als Amaterasu, die japanische Sonnengöttin, die die Gestalt eines legendären weißen Wolfs angenommen hat, um einen achtköpfigen Dämonen zu besiegen. Dieser Dämon hat dazu hauptsächlich beigetragen, dass der Ort "Nippon" zu einer verfallenen Ödnis geworden ist. Die Geschichte rund um den weißen Wolf wurde sehr gut in Szene gesetzt und kann wirklich überzeugen. Auch wenn der Titel schon einige Jahre auf den Buckel hat, möchte man sich immer wieder in diese wunderschöne Geschichte verlieren. Somit haben die Entwickler um Punkt "Story" schon damals ganze Arbeit geleistet, doch was hat sich bei dem HD-Remake geändert? Somit kommen wir nun zum Punkt "Grafik". 

Grafik:
Die Grafik von Okami HD ist wirklich beeindruckend und die Tuschmalereien kamen noch nie so gut rüber wie in diesem HD-Remake. Und mit der passenden PC-Hardware gibt es das Meisterwerk sogar in wunderschöner 4K-Grafik. Im Punkt "Grafik" wirkt der Titel einfach zeitlos und lässt sich immer wieder gerne erleben. In der Testphase kamen keine Bugs bzw. Grafikfehler vor, somit ist der Titel schon jetzt ein wirkliches Highlight zum kleinen Preis. Des Weiteren ist das HD-Remake wahlweise im klassischen 4:3- oder im 16:9-Format spielbar und es gibt wieder die Ladebildschirm-Minispiele, welche leider in der Wii- und PlayStation 3-Version fehlten. Somit kann der Titel im Punkt "Grafik" wirklich voll uns ganz Punkten, und auch wenn der Titel schon 2006 erschien, hat Okami nichts von seinem damaligen Charme verloren. Und nun geht es auch zum nächsten Punkt dem Gameplay. 

Gameplay:
Im Punkt "Gameplay" setzt der Titel auf eine sehr gute spielerische Vielfalt. Als legendärer weißer Wolf verfügen wir nämlich über zwei unterschiedliche Waffentypen, um eine Vielzahl von dämonischen Gegnern zuvernichten. Die Pinseltechniken, die wir während des Spielverlaufs erlernen, sind auch eines der Highlights des Titels. Im Punkt "Gameplay" kann der Titel auch wie damals immer noch voll und ganz überzeugen, die Missionen wirken schön gestaltet und Ingesamt setzte sich das Gameplay aus allerlei kleinen Highlights zusammen. Hier kann der Titel überzeugen und langweilig bzw. eintönig wird das Gameplay zu keiner Zeit und bei der PC-Steuerung gibt es keine Komplikationen. Und nun kommen wir auch schon zum Sound des HD-Remakes. 

Sound:
Hier im Punkt "Sound" bietet der Titel eine wirklich stimmungsvolle Soundkulisse, welche immer perfekt zum Spielgeschehen passt. Sprachausgaben gibt es leider nicht wirklich und die Oberfläche wird in vielen Sprachen übermittelt. Alle Soundeffekte wurden sehr gut in das innovative Gameplay eingebaut und können auch wirklich zu jeder Zeit überzeugen. Hier gibt es wirklich nichts zu bemängeln und die Entwickler haben beim HD-Remake alles richtig gemacht.

Fazit:
Das HD-Remake von Okami sollte sich wirklich niemand entgehen lassen. Auch wenn der Titel schon 2006 für die PlayStation 2 veröffentlicht wurde, ist der Titel kein Jahr älter geworden und wirkt wie eine sehr schön gestaltete Spielperle. Die Geschichte rund um den weißen legendären Wolf wird sehr schön erzählt und das Gameplay hat nichts von seinem damaligen Charme verloren. Des Weiteren kann die Grafik mit ihrem eigenen Stil sehr gut punkten. Wie schon erwähnt, wer Okami nicht kennen sollte, darf sich diesen Titel zum kleinen Preis nicht entgehen lassen. Und wir können nur hoffen, dass das Sequel Ōkamiden es vielleicht auch irgendwann auf die Konsole bzw. PC schaffen wird.

Okami is a Guiness World Record holder.  For real.  However, it's not a very good one, as Okami is the least commercially successful winner of a game of the year award (2006) in gaming history.  To call this an underappreciated classic is an understatement.  However, as part of the problem, I've never played this game until recently.  When this game came out for Steam, I decided to give this HD re-release a shot.  What a game.  Why the hell didn't I play this sooner?

The player controls Amaterasu, the Shinto goddess of the sun in the form of a wolf.  With the help of Issun, a wandering artist, Amaterasu runs around Nippon gathering up all the abilities she lost from before in order to save Nippon from evil.  Along the way, Amaterasu befriends allies and battles enemies to achieve this goal.  That's really all I care to speak about the story, due to potential spoilers and the sheer length of the game.  Okami took me 40 hours to beat, and that's without grinding for any particular item or anything.  It simply has an epic tale that is a joy to experience.

At first play, it is impossible for the player to not notice the unique graphics Okami uses.  I firmly believe that cel-shaded games benefit most from these HD remakes, and Okami takes almost full advantage.  The watercolor vibe really does give this game a ton of character, and it being in HD helps keep its graphics looking great even in 2018.  Every single level has immense character due to this, from the foliage of the trees to the evil emanating from enemies.  At some points, seeing the sky blue colors contrast with the sunset red is simply awe-inspiring.  Okami is truly a beautiful game.

However, there is one issue that ties in with the graphics -- this game is 30fps in gameplay (60fps in menus).  This was an initial problem for me, as I play first-person shooters in 144+fps, so my eyes had to adjust to the blur.  This is probably moreso a problem for PC Master Race gamers, who expect more out of any game today.  However, being that Okami was originally a PS2 title, the framerate is tied in with its physics and gameplay.  I'd rather have a fun game to play at 30fps than a broken game at higher framerates, and as my eyes adjusted, this became a non-issue.

The only other thing about Okami is that, well, it's incredibly easy.  I promise I say this without bragging, but I didn't come close to dying once during the 40 hour playthrough.  However, in an age where people claim things like, "Crash Bandicoot is the Dark Souls of platformers," maybe its lack of difficulty isn't the worst thing in the world.  Should the player want a challenge, there are no other difficulty levels, but Okami enthusiasts told me its de-facto "hard mode" is playing without upgrades.  Its difficulty could also be interpreted as child-friendly, too, for parents looking for a gift for their kid to play.  Ultimately, this is a non-problem.

That's because Okami is just so much fun to play.  It is incredibly charming, with memorable characters, an epic story, and an engaging adventure.  Its combat is so simple, but it works so well.  Amaterasu's main ability is her Celestial Brush, which allows her to use a multitude of abilities against enemies while attacking.  This is done very well both with a controller or with a mouse and keyboard.  The exchange between painting your enemies to death while attacking them is seamless and also satisfying.  This style of gameplay help make Okami's boss battles clever and fun to fight.  The brush abilities extend to out of combat, too, where they're used to complete puzzles and progress to new areas in the game.  These aspects all make Okami a rewarding and satisfying game to play, despite its lack of difficulty.

The sound deserves a special mention, too.  The music is wonderful.  Okami is a very chill game to play, and its music fits within the mood of the world Okami creates, whatever the situation.  Thematically, it showcases a style of traditional Japanese music that matches the Shinto backstory it tells, and really helps immerse the player into the story or the battle.  The sound effects are almost as vibrant as the graphics themselves.  The "dialogue" comes from the school of Banjo-Kazooie, and its Sims-ish speech only lends to the game's charm, in my opinion.  The sound this game delivers is on the same level as every other aspect of it -- excellence.

However, Okami's brilliance is its ability to tie all of its excellent parts together into one amazing package.  Its gameplay gimmick ties in with Okami's graphics itself, which dovetails perfectly with its music, which is further buttressed by its story, which showcases the charming characters, and so on.  All these aspects complement each other so well, it makes Okami the brilliant game that it is.  And while this game wasn't fully appreciated in the past, I'm glad that we get a second chance to experience playing it in 2018 and beyond.  It would be a shame to continually miss out.

Okami is a masterpiece.

39081177.review:
[h1] One of the best games ever created. [/h1]

This is my third time doing a full playthrough of this incredibly unique game - first on PS2, second on the Wii, now on PC. 

[b] Why I think it deserves the accolades [/b]:

+ [b] Sound [/b]: The music is nothing short of brilliant; the compositions span the whole spectrum of eerily haunting to whimsically playful, from morose longing to exuberant joy whilst remaining quintissentially Japanese in style throughout. 

+ [b] Graphics [/b]: The art style is unique and detailed - you can stop playing the game and admire the scenic views at almost any point. The cell shading emulates a Japanese bamboo painting style, it's really effective, it's like playing a moving painting. 

+ [b] Story [/b]: Equally expressive as the music, you'll be taken through a wild array of situations many of which are wholly unexpected and hilariously bizarre. To put the story simply; you are a god that has lost its power and needs to rejuvenate the once bustling land of medieval rural Nippon. You'll meet animals, people, spirits and monsters, dealing with their problems or malevolence helps restore the vitality of the myriad locations you will encounter, FeelsGoodMan

+ [b] Gameplay [/b]: Comparisons to Zelda are justified; there is close combat, there are large scale puzzles, there are upgradable items and buffs, but none of these feel ripped off from the Zelda series - Okami forges its own path and it feels more seamless than pre-BOTW Zelda games. Dungeons are an extension of the world rather than something you've been locked in until you beat the boss. The difficulty is just about right too, there's plenty of play styles to be utlized in bouts and the brush techniques and various weapons cater to this. That being said, once you get into your groove most fights - that aren't a boss - become easier but still rewarding and fun because the quicker and more efficiently you win a fight the better the cash prize. 

Length-wise this game could last you 50 hours easily for a thorough first-time playthrough. I sped through this time finishing in less that 30 hours, even though it was my 3rd time playing I still thoroughly enjoyed it.

A minor note goes to performance: no graphical/sound/framerate errors at all throughout my playthrough. Also, [i] the mouse and keyboard support is great. [/i]

[b] Criticisms of the port [/b]:

- [b] Resolution/Framerate [/b]: AMD's super resolution and NVIDIA's equivalent cannot be used for this game it seems, which is annoying as it's great to play old games with the res put up to 4k and see just how good older games can stand the test of time - sadly, Okami is locked to your screen's native res. or below. It's also locked to 30fps and due to the engine's fundamentals will most likely never change from this in the future - though it's always smooth. As someone that is a big 60fps advocate I have to say the 30fps cap didn't hinder my playthrough anywhere near as much as I thought it would.

However I HIGHLY recommend installing Steam user Kaldaien's Special K mod that allows you to turn off Grain and Bloom easily which makes the game look a whole lot cleaner and 'HD' - apparently he's working on 60fps too...

- [b] Controls and camera angles [/b] - Occasionally the game struggles to register where your celestial  brush is positioned and even though you think you may have done the brush work right you'll find out you haven't. The camera angles and horizontal movement of the camera can also be frustrating as you will sometimes lose track of where your enemies are or even where your character is, coupled with the fact that you cannot change the horizontal camera speed with the controller makes for some clunky/aggrevating moments - fortunately this problem isn't prevalent. 

- [b] Controller [/b] - At first I thought my wireless Xbox 360 controller wasn't supported - it turns out the game is just picky, I needed to turn my controller on before I even opened up Steam to make sure Okami realized the controller was there. After that it works flawlessly and you can switch to KB&M seamlessly too.

[b] Conclusion [/b]: If you like rich, expansive storytelling, Japanese folklore, ellaborate but whistlable oriental music, Zelda-style RPG elements, and addictive gameplay then Okami would be a crime to pass up - BUY IT and hopefully Capcom will force Clover Studios to be reborn to make another Okami masterpiece.

[h1] Conclusión:  [/h1] 

Excelente juego, recomendado incluso sin estar en oferta, pese a que ya tiene sus años, no ha envejecido mal por su tipo de gráficos, además, tiene un estilo artistico muy japones, buena banda sonora y una excelente mecanica que lo mantiene interesante.

38969548.review:
I own this game for PS2.  I own this game for Wii.  I own this game for PS3.  And now I own it for PC.

Having beaten this game at least 2 or three times on multiple consoles, I can confidently say this is an excellent port.

In Okami, you play as an incarnation of the sun goddess Amaterasu (Ammy for short) trying to save the world from darkness and evil.  Having woken up from a hundred year-long absence, Ammy is now much weaker compared to 100 years ago, and must find the other gods in order to regain her strength and abilities to face the trials ahead.

These abilities primarily consist of Celestial Brush techniques, which allow you to paint designs that can slash like a sword, create fire from nothing, or change night into day (she [b] is [/b] the sun goddess, after all).  New abilities, much like new items in Legend of Zelda games, will also allow you to make your way further in the world, unlocking new areas and a plethora of hidden secrets.

Gameplay is fun, as long as you're not looking for highly complex combo systems.  For those that don't much care for combat, a lot of it is optional, and combat has no effect on improving Ammy's stats.

Okami controls very nicely, with keyboard + mouse controls as good as a playstation controller (better for those more comfortable with a keyboard than a controller).  Mouse controls for the paintbrush are probably the best of all systems, as it takes a bit of practice to master using an analog stick or the Wiimote.  The mouse, simply put, feels more natural.  I played using a keyboard so I cannot attest to how well PC Okami plays using a controller.

While I don't consider graphics to be a deal-breaker, it's still nice to have something pretty to look at.  And Okami is [b] gorgeous [/b] .  I don't just mean for an eleven year-old game; I mean just in general.  Vibrant colors and an art style reminiscent of a Japanese painting mean that Okami ages much more gracefully than most games (though the first area can be a little hard on the eyes and, visually, is one of my least favorite areas).  If you know what to look for, you can easily see places where the game shows its age, but overall, the game still looks beautiful.

While I feel I've spent too many words on this review already, I [b] have [/b] to mention the soundtrack.  Always appropriate to the mood of the scene (or very deliberately not), many tracks are just plain beautiful, with the exceptions generally being deliberately silly or fun.  The one great shame is that the original credits song is (I hear, being near the end but not yet having beaten PC Okami as of the writing of this review) is absent, as it has been from every port of the game.
EDIT:  Having completed Okami, I can confirm that, sadly, the original credits song has been replaced by something else.

Some minor issues I had that were no more than mild annoyances:
[olist]
[*] Occasionally, when moving, the canvas (mapped to ctrl) would come up while I was only pressing the movement keys.  I haven't yet figured out why.
[*] In the fishing minigame, the keys used to yank fish out of the water are sometimes the same ones used to reel them in, which, when it happened, would result in me yanking the fish out when I wasn't ready to.  For those not familiar with the minigame, you need to bring up the canvas using ctrl within a second or two after yanking it out of the water or else the fish will fall back in and you have to repeat the reeling process.  Sometimes (not always) I would be caught by surprise enough that I missed that window.
[*] My computer is not that great, so I could, for the mosts part, only run Okami on "medium" graphics or else face significant lag and cutscenes with unsynched audio and visuals, and for one boss battle had to drop the graphics to "low."  Even playing on "low," though, the game is still gorgeous.
[/olist]

And for veterans of the PS2 version:  [b] the loading screen minigames are back! [/b]

Overall, Okami is excellent.  If you like Legend of Zelda, games that look like you're playing a painting, games that have a painting mechanic, or some old fashioned, albeit simple, demon-bashing, I think you'll like this game.

Allerdings muss ich einen kleinen Kritikpunkt an die Deutsche Fassung niederschreiben. Ändern tut diese Kritik auch nichts mehr an dem Game, aber es ist schon schade das die Kreativität da ein wenig gelitten hat. Issun kann zig anzügliche, zweideutige Bemerkungen hinaushauen, aber bei einer Reaktion auf etwas erschreckendes, fällt ihm nur was zur Hölle ein.
Naja beim zweiten Durchlauf skippe ich die Dialoge sowieso aber jetzt der Nostalgie halber lese ich sie mir ganz gerne mal wieder durch. Da  fällt es dann schon reichlich auf.. xD

ABER NUN DENN.
Langer Rede und kein Sinn, davon abgesehen ändert das wie gesagt nichts daran, dass dieses Game vor schönen Momenten und Überraschungen nur so überquillt und sicherlich jeder seinen Spaß damit haben kann!

38716315.review:
It should be noted that controller support, atleast in the case for the ds4 in my experience, is well supported. The issue at first was that pressing x or o while the game loads does not activate the controller. Instead, one must press start. Seems odd but not a dealbreaker.

As for the game itself, its most certainly a fun game but i do have my gripes. Although my play hours seem low ive played for much longer in offline mode for personal circumstances. I have yet to complete the game but i think ive played enough this far to make a fair judgement.

First and foremost, the game has TONS of collectibles. You'll constantly find yourself backtracking to collect praise or stray beads after collecting a new brush technique. You have to feed animals, rejuvenate trees, and much more in order to collect praise, which you can call the equivalent to "exp" of sorts used to upgrade a trait of your choice. Praise can also be acquired from story progression for that matter. The issue is how ever that the amount you get for each one is rather small, counterbalanced by the sheer number of collectible praise. At some point it becomes a bit of a chore that takes away from being able to enjoy the main game. Of course you can just do any praise collecting thats happens to be in your path but why gimp yourself for the lategame? At the very least the game has lists of sorts for some of these collectibles, but not all of them, such as for rejuvenating clovers.

The game is also bogged a bit more by constant hand holding. Occasionally some hand holding is needed. For example, when your given the crescent brush technique to make it night time, youre supposed to make a simple curved line from top to bottom. I kept making a full backwards c from bottom to top, frustrated until the game pointed out exactly how to make the proper stroke. Japanese stroke order is serious business. Beyond that however youre constantly given text explaining everything even after its already obvious what solution is needed for a given circumstance. Some dialogue here and there cant be sped up, and constant story dialogue that tends to be needlessly long is peppered through out the game. I feel the game could be trimmed about a quarter of the total play time just by removing needless text and dialogue.

The game is also relatively easy. You'll hardly find yourself struggling against encountered enemies and bosses. Bosses tend to be slow and their gimmick as obvious as broad daylight. The game doesnt quite require the technical skill in combat as say zelda for instance. Bear in mind ive only fought 4 actual bosses thus far so perhaps its to early to say that other bosses may not require more skill, but when i havent gone below 75% of my health once the entire game the difficulty becomes questionable. Its laughable that theres a mechanic that once fully upgraded allows you to be revived up to 4 times(if i understand correctly) during a fight. I have to wonder if the team behind the game wasnt sure if they wanted a younger or older demoographic for the game during development, or if the play testers have never touched an action game once in their life.

Anyways, for the modest price of the game id still reccomend picking up the game. Even for a zeldaesque game it rivals smaller and older jrpgs for completion time. Enjoy the game and take your time making your progress while you enjoy the beautiful visuals of okami.

Okami war schon auf der Wii großartig und ich bin überrascht, wie gut es sich am PC spielen lässt. Das Zeichnen mit der Maus funktioniert gut und auch der Rest der Steuerung ist für einen Port sehr gelungen. Einen Controller hiermit zum Laufen zu bringen fand ich allerdings eher schwierig, kommt aber sicherlich auch auf das Modell an.

Das Spiel selbst ist schwierig zu beschreiben. Es ist kein Zelda-Clon, auch wenn es natürlich Ähnlichkeiten gibt. Die Pinseltechniken funktionieren wie Waffen und Werkzeuge und werden vielfältig in die Rätsel eingebunden. Außerdem bietet das Spiel meiner Meinung nach genau die richtige Balance aus An-die-Hand-nehmen und Selbst-ausprobieren-lassen. Wenn man beispielsweise mehrmals an einem Minispiel scheitert, gibt das Spiel oft zusätzliche Hinweise, um einem unter die Arme zu greifen.

Einziger Kritikpunkt ist für mich, dass es manchmal zu Laggs kommt. Generell scheint es noch ein paar technische Probleme zu geben, da auch manche von Abstürzen und ähnlichen Problemen berichten. Laggs - wie in meinem Fall - sind ein bisschen nervig, da es viele Rätsel gibt, bei denen Timing wichtig ist und die Pinseltechniken verfehlen ihre Wirkung, wenn der Strich nicht akkurat genug gesetzt wird. Bisher bin ich aber trotzdem gut durch das Spiel durchgekommen.

Nichtsdestotrotz ist Okami ein Meisterwerk. Nicht nur grafisch und akustisch, sondern auch durch seine Geschichte und die Untertöne. Es macht einfach Spaß, man kann sich stundenlang darin verlieren, Rätseln, erkunden und Schätze suchen und sammeln oder einfach nur die einzigartige Umgebung bewundern.

38667971.review:
There should be a wall of text here first but you know what? Screw that. 

I'll be blunt: Okami, in my opinion, is one of the few games which HAS to be in everyone's Top 10 games of all time. Period.

Story: 8.0/10
[i]The game is set in a Nippon (Japan) based on Japanese folklore and begins in one hundred years in the past. The narrator describes how the white wolf Shiranui and swordsman Nagi fought and sealed the eight-headed demon Orochi at the cave, to save Kamiki Village and Nagi's beloved maiden Nami.

In the game's present, Nagi's descendant and self-proclaimed greatest warrior, Susano, refuses to believe in Nagi's legend and frees Orochi, who escapes and curses the lands, sapping the life from Nippon. Sakuya, the wood sprite and guardian of Kamiki Village, calls forth Amaterasu, the sun goddess, known to the villagers as the reincarnation of the white wolf Shiranui, and asks her to remove the curse that covers the land. Accompanied by the artist Issun (an inch-high creature known as a Poncle), Amaterasu begins to restore the land to its normal state.[/i]

Sound: 9.5/10
With 4 CD's the soundtrack is packed with hours. If you say "Quality over quantity" though then jokes on you, the quality is just as good. Sadly the ending song "Reset" from the PS2 version is missing which really hurts.

Graphics: 10/10
The paint brush style hast been beautiful ten years ago, it still is and it'll be even in 50 years.

Presentation: 9.5/10 
+ The overworld is big. Speedrunning from the two furthest points away might take you quite a while.
+ Super lovely characters. Dialogues with the residents are interesting to read, too.
+ When you think the game's end is near, you'll be at the halfway point. Nice surprise factor.
+ The final part of Okami (which still takes about 10 hours to finish) really raise the stakes.
- The Banjo-Kazooie-like voiceover is not as pleasent in here like in most of those N64 era-games.
 
 
Gameplay: 9.5/10  
+ Similar to the likes of Zelda, Darksiders and other action adventures
+ A LOT of secrets and collectibles
+++The celestial paintbrush mechanic
- Playing it after 10 years, the camera movement could be somewhat more responsive.
- Really easy game, almost impossible to die. There's a workaround though: Don't upgrade your equipment/status plus refrain from using items and you'll be up to a challenge.

Final rating: [b]94/100[/b]

38645392.review:
This game is still beautiful and fun as I remembered it. You play as a wolf, roaming the land to restore it to its former beauty. As a wolf you can do things like dig, bark, bite and recieve pat albiet only from  a few npc. Only dig have gameplay signficance but you can still prompt reaction from people. There a lot to do in this game, sidequest, collectable and even fishing. Your main method of gaining upgrade is aquiring praise, which you get for restoring land, helping people and feeding animals. As you progress through the story you unlock brush technique. There is a lot of interactivity with the enviroment that involve the brush technique thats worth disovering on your own. The brush technique lets you gain access to new area or treasures that were previously unreachable. 

Combat is equally prominent in okami as you'll need to slay the demons that are contaminating the land. Combat is standard action hack and slash but what make it special the interaction enemy have with the brush technique. Enemy will have certain weakness/resistance to brush technique for example the red imp instrument can be destroyed with slash brush technique when its been raised to block attack. Combat is not difficult and rather forgiving, at least for me. Those who are struggling could always use consumable which there are plenty and can be bought. The real challenge is to obtain blossom ranking at the end of combat. The game rewards you with more currency for beating enemy quickly and not taking damage. It is very difficult to obtain blossom rank on boss fight assuming you don't plan on save scumming or retrying. Its in your best interest to not die in the game as there is a game performance score at the end of the game which grant rewards. Thankfully time is not part of the game peformance score so you can take your time beating the game.

It runs fine on low specs machine and even on low quality the game is still georgeous.  Graphic option are lacking not that you would need a lot, but I would at least like view distance. If you running low spec remember to set your option before you starting the game, you don't want to listen to Issun and Sakuya for an agonising half an hour of unskippable dialogue due to the lag.

As a port, the biggest disappointment is the lack of mouse support for the menu. You have to navigate with keyboard. It would of been nice to have a brush cursor. Otherwise the game runs smoothly and the controls work.

Edit*
I forgot to mention about the beautiful soundtrack. Its consist of traditional japanese instrument, the flute work is amazing. It works really well with the paint brush aesthetic.

Pros:
- Ridiculously well worth for the price tag, $20 is such a steal for this game
- Great even for people that played it when it first came out; the updated graphics are absolutely beautiful
- Gameplay is as fun as ever, with lots and lots of sidequests and unique minigames
- The story and all the NPCs in the game are both fun and interesting
- Using the brush with the mouse is way easier (imo) than using a controller

Honestly, I played this game as a kid and was worried it wouldn't hold up. I've played this game twice before, at different stages in my life. But being around 2 hours into it, I can definitely say that it matches my fond memories, if not exceeds it due to the updated graphics. 

There are a few cons, though, mostly technical issues:
- Camera can feel kind of wonky with a mouse; I had to spend a while changing the sensitivity
- Laggy in windowed mode
- The text in major cutscenes is slow as FUCK. The opening cutscene is like 20 minutes long and there's lots of unskippable cutscenes. The story is great so it's not that it's boring, it's just so... so slow.

The technical issues are just minor cons in the grand scheme of things though. Like pretty much everyone else, I would recommend this game whether or not you've played it before. There's really just no other game like this.

38620603.review:
[h1]如慈母般照亮世界，化身天照大神展開救世之旅[/h1]

《大神》是日本遊戲廠商 CAPCOM 於 2006 年在 PS2 平台販售的動作冒險遊戲，事隔十一年的今日，終於移植到 PC 平台，筆者從《大神》移植到 Wii 平台時，便知道這款遊戲有多麼的傑出，採用風格獨特的水墨畫風為基底，再以趣味性十足的筆調系統為壓軸，透過解鎖十三筆神所賦予的力量，破解遭遇到的難題和斬殺四處作亂的卑劣妖怪。本作的故事劇情主要講述很久很久以前，有一座名作神木村的小聚落，這裡存在著不成文的傳統習俗，就是在每年祭典之夜到來時，都要將村裡最美麗的少女獻祭給八岐大蛇，今年被選定的少女叫做伊邪娜美，得知此消息的伊邪那岐無法接受這項事實，決定挺身而出挑戰八岐大蛇，然而就在雙方戰得你死我活之際，伊邪那岐終究不是八岐大蛇的對手，所幸一匹全身雪白的白狼出現，協助伊邪那岐戰勝八岐大蛇，而那匹白狼的名字不叫傑洛特，而是天照大神。

就這樣和平的一百年過去了，年輕一輩的人們逐漸忘記這段歷史，某日，封印著八岐大蛇的十六夜祠堂出現一名質疑神話的神秘人，他一手拔起了當初斬斷八岐大蛇的神劍月呼，這一舉動讓八岐大蛇重新降臨在日本，祂所經之處必定充滿災厄，大地被邪氣覆蓋，太陽被濃霧拒於門外，生活在這片土地的居民與神靈都被其影響，大家期盼著傳說中的伊邪那岐再次拯救日本，不過這次挺身而出挑戰八岐大蛇的不是祂，而是被木精咲耶姬從百年沉睡中甦醒的天照大神。大家應該不難看出《大神》劇情主幹源自於日本和銅五年（西元712年）由太安萬侶所編撰日本古代歷史書籍《古事記》，儘管故事內容跟原著有不少區別，但仍然能協助對日本神話歷史不太熟悉的玩家進行初步認識，知曉研究神話歷史的樂趣所在。


[h1]拜訪十三筆神，尋回神力再次迎戰八岐大蛇[/h1]

筆調系統是《大神》最具特色的原創玩法，天照大神在與八岐大蛇大戰後導致能力喪失，為了找回屬於自己的能力，我們要在探險途中尋找象徵十二生肖（追加一隻貓神）掌控十三種筆調的筆神們，在一開始的新手教學會遇到蘇神（生肖屬龍），祂賦予大神復原物件的力量，咱們只要在破損的器具或橋梁上畫出原本應該存在的部位，就可以順利修復它們，這項功能主要是用來破解謎題。過沒多久又遇到了斷神（生肖屬鼠），祂將給予大神一閃能力，顧名思義就是劃出一道橫線，橫線筆墨化為劍氣斬斷所經事物，是遊戲內最主要的戰鬥方式，針對敵人弱點施展一閃，通常會給予對方極大傷害，不少頭目戰都需要靠一閃獲勝。

除了上述的兩種基本筆調之外，還有機會學習弓神（兔子）、爆神（豬）、三神（猴子）等特殊筆調，每種筆調都需要玩家利用神筆劃出不同的圖形觸動其應有的作用，以弓神為例，祂的功用是讓早晨轉為夜晚，在天空畫下半月型的筆調，瞬間更改天象；爆神提供創造炸彈的功能，畫出圓圈後在頂端拉出一條線，即可變化出炸彈，不僅能用於戰鬥擊敗妖怪，還能破壞脆弱的牆面發掘新的道路；三神的效果較為多元，咲之花神能夠讓枯萎的植物開花令大地重獲生命、蓮之花神會在水面生長荷葉供天照大神立足、蔦之花神提供大神空中移動功能，對著浮在半空的桃花拉出線條，藤蔓會將天照大神拉往該處。總而言之，我們可以將筆調當作是用於破解特殊謎題的能力或是道具，如同鑰匙與鑰匙孔的概念，表面看似複雜，實際運用上很簡單易懂。


[h1]化解難題蒐集幸玉，多多益善總會有好事發生[/h1]

關於角色強化系統，不用消滅怪物也能獲取幸玉（既經驗值），遊戲中到處都能看見枯萎的櫻花樹，這時只要利用咲之花神的開花筆調，讓枯萎的櫻花盛開就可以取得幸玉，另外解決他人煩惱、餵食野生動物、淨化汙染之地，也會獲得幸玉，有了足夠的幸玉就能夠提升生命值與墨水罐上限。多虧遊戲難度不太困難，要卡關是一件十分困難的事，由於目前 Steam 版本尚未支援繁體中文語系，筆者最常遭遇到的困難來自任務目標提示的不明確，絕大多數的任務不會有系統指引告訴玩家要如何完成，我們只能細心閱讀 NPC 標註紅色字體話語，分析該前往的目的地、需要尋找的某位人物、以及執行觸發任務的特定行為。


[h1]詼諧取代嚴肅，使大眾更容易接受神話題材作品[/h1]

故事劇情方面，《大神》採取直白的敘述手法，百年前被封印的八岐大蛇又一次肆虐日本，天照大神和一寸法師開始周遊各國，為人民解決問題的同時，也接受神祉們的協助，神祇幫天照大神累積足夠的神力，最終與八岐大蛇決一死戰，重新將光明帶回世間。既然每個人都知道最終結局一定是快樂結局，那麼要如何讓玩家感受到截然不同的神話故事呢？製作團隊決定從重塑角色性格和劇情做起，使用幽默詼諧的演出讓玩家拋棄神話故事總是冗長無趣的刻板印象，其中最令筆者印象深刻的是經常出現在天照面前的陰陽師牛若（牛若丸），日文夾雜英文的說話方式（英文版字幕則是英文夾雜法文），讓人十分出戲，更不用說祂的戰鬥方式是拿出《星際大戰》神兵光劍飛天遁地，活像是跑錯攝影棚的穿越劇主角。

從遊戲性來看，《大神》可說是一口氣兼顧喜愛動作冒險、益智解謎、故事賞析此三大族群玩家，熱愛戰鬥的玩家能在夜晚時間挑戰懸賞榜上的凶惡妖怪進而領取報酬；對解謎情有獨鍾的玩家可以在不時出現的小遊戲中得到破解謎題的滿足感；假如你不喜歡打鬥和解謎，可以無視除主線之外的支線玩法，一口氣直接將遊戲通關，得到閱讀互動式有聲書的相同體驗。換句話說，絕大多數的玩家一定會在本作得到樂趣，外加天照大神和一寸法師的互動極為逗趣，天照大神無論是在跑步、游泳、挖洞、睡覺、甚至是賭氣的表情都能讓人卸下平時累積的壓力，跟著作品中的人物共同感受喜怒哀樂，獲得身心兩方的喜悅感。


[h1]實至名歸，不玩可惜的跨世代經典名作[/h1]

或許有些人認為《大神》是款過譽的作品，我必須承認本作確實不是完美的作品，但其詩意般的水墨畫風就現今而言，還是沒有遊戲有能力重現並超越它，多達十三種功能的筆調系統，操作起來不僅不卡手，反而讓人輕鬆駕馭，靠著想像力為冒險帶來無窮可能性，最後透過幽默詼諧的方式詮釋日本古神話讓年輕人重新思考神話歷史的重要性。《大神》之所以能在十一年後的今日又被提起一定有其理由存在，粉絲們極度想要遊戲總監神谷英樹為《大神》製作續作的原因非常單純，大家熱愛這部作品，認為它是值得花時間等待的好遊戲，反觀另一款同樣十多年沒有新作的《戰慄時空》，已經是爹不疼娘不愛的棄子了。


[h1]優缺點總整理[/h1]

優點：
+十三筆神分別代表十三種能力，看似複雜難精通，實質上簡單易懂好上手。
+整體難度偏易，就算沒有刻意蒐集幸玉也不會卡關，對新手玩家非常友善。
+水墨畫風如詩如畫，操縱天照大神在大地圖奔跑十分痛快，壓力頓時散去。
+時而嚴肅，時而輕鬆，腳本撰寫傑出，人物有血有淚，共同體會喜怒哀樂。


缺點：
-戰鬥系統過於單調，升級系統過於簡略，若是能加入些許變化會更為完美。


結論：名符其實的神作，熱愛日本神話和動作冒險遊戲的玩家都該嘗試遊玩。

This game is probably the best game I’ve ever played. I played it when it came out for the Wii and in the end, I have 37 completed saves on my Wii with 15 unfinished ones. 

Before I go anywhere with this I need to say: the port is amazing. Hearing about it I thought my computer would heat up trying to run it like it does with most ports. But it has no troubles running it at all so, I’m pretty happy about that. 

The game keeps your attention with interesting story telling and amazing gameplay. The game has its bugs of course but none of them are huge from my knowledge. The biggest bug I’ve run into is an audio bug with the transformers. 

However I’ve heard of people having trouble with controllers. I use a mouse and keyboard to play so I cannot say anything there. 

The game caps at 30 FPS but I honestly couldn’t care less. It looks and feels exactly like the original and that’s all I care about. Sure, it would have been great at 60 FPS. But they announced that they tried to make it 60 and it broke the game pretty badly. So to me, it’s something very small and has little impact. 

You controls are fluid and don’t expect you to be all over the place at once. The battles are fantastic, the weapons work and feel fluid. They give you options on how you want to fight with three types of weapons and the additional secondary weapon you are able to use to deal extra damage or give yourself defense so it’s a very flexible game. 

In the end: I would say buy it. If you’re into amazing storytelling then this is the game for you. The game is extremely interactive with so many extra features and things to do. Extra side quests and lore that you can only uncover by going out of your way to look for. 

What I will say though is that, this game does not hold your hand. If you’re looking for a game that drags you where you need to be then this game won’t be very easy. The game incourages exploring and problem solving. But that’s not saying they don’t block off areas you’re not suppose to be in. The game will nudge you but a lot of the game is taking hints. Anything important to where you are going next will be red text instead of black however so that helps. I never had problems with it but I know some friends who got stuck at certain points in the game (all pretty much the same points) so I thought I’d add that. 

Overall, I’d say get the game if you’re considering it. But be prepared to solve things on your own. (Or look up tutorials lol)

I played this through on the ps2 a whole Gregorian decade ago and had fond memories.
I bought this HD revamp and asked for a refund shortly after. Here's why...

I'm sorry to say that the HD seal is only applicable to some of the game art. You will sit through a painfully tedious low-res intro for what feels like an eternity before you start to exert some agency. By then the mawkish faux language of npcs really starts to grind. The control scheme -on controller- was alarmingly poor. The video angles consistently felt wrong and you keep having to reset the camera to face forwards. Then the unforgivably poorly mapped brush events start up in the orientation. The brush is not easy to control. It was not in the least bit fun. after several bodged attempts I randomly dabbed it about in a fit of exasperation. Et voila that worked better than the concerted efforts and got me through to the next screen. If you can make it past that point you have the endurance of Mo Farah's feet. I would admire anyone who does, if it wasn't simultaneously so pitiably senseless. 

I have a strong suspicion that the deliberate decision not to cast an editorial eye over this game was made in some misguided attempt to preserve its purity. A cursory amount of work on the perspective camera would have made this game immeasurably better. The devs did not even bother to upscale some of the art. As it stands the game creaks like a ten-year-old game would. It seems a real missed opportunity and one any right-minded person would pass on.

Okami est un excellent jeu qui n'a pas connu le succès qu'il méritait à l'époque, cette version pc permet à nombre de gens d'enfin pouvoir y jouer sans problème (enfin pour ceux qui n'ont pas déjà recouru à l'émulation Wii ou ps2). Et une excellente occasion pour les autre de le refaire.
 Pour ce qui est du portage en lui même il est néanmoins regrettable de voir certaines choses ternir le tableau: La première c'est le poids du jeu : 30 GB, c'est 15 fois plus que l'ISO ps2, je veut bien croire que les textures HD prennent plus de place mais à ce point là c'est vraiment n'importe quoi.
 La seconde c'est l'optimisation, alors ne vous y trompez pas le jeu respecte parfaitement le cahier des charges (1080p/30fps) sur ma machine même si je pense qu'on était en droit d'attendre du 60 fps. Néanmoins gros coup de gueule quand on regarde l'usage CPU: 80% SUR UN i5 4670k!!! A la manière d'assassin's creed origin je soupçonne l'éditeur d'avoir employé un DRM des plus exigent, c'est d'autant plus abbérant qu'à coté le jeu ne consomme que 250 Mo de Ram et que le GPU se touche la nouille.

学学别人先上评价：
优点：
1. 出色的剧情+
2. 优秀的战斗系统，不错的打击感+
3. 富含创意的游戏设计，使用笔调解密+
4. 优美的游戏原声和主题曲+++

缺点：
1. 画面精细度不足
2. 没有中文


美轮美奂的场景，充满和风的画面和音乐，完美衔接的日式神话故事，完全不会出戏的搞笑对话，共同构成了这幅波澜壮阔的冒险绘卷。如果你喜欢或了解日本文化，你将会在这里面找到无数的彩蛋，每一个都让你会心一笑；如果你还不了解日文化，你也会叹服于这里面的各种故事的。

游戏的战斗系统也设计的恰到好处，镜剑玉三神器作为能装备的三种武器，有各自的战斗特点，再加上表里2种装备模式，总共6种战斗方式，在配合上笔调系统，可以有各种各样的组合来解决对手，特别是针对不同类型的敌人，当你悟出使用什么笔调来针对他们的时候，战斗往往能事半功倍。

总体而言，这个游戏即使作为近两年的新游戏推出也丝毫没有任何落伍的地方，画面上的不足由于采用水墨的独特渲染方式并不会成为她的短板，原价购入不敢说物超所值，但至少是物有所值的，更何况现在还送天照大神帮你刀塔运道具，还要啥自行车。


对于很多差评里所说的锁30帧的问题，我并不认为锁30帧对这个游戏来说有什么影响，首先她并不是强调极限操作的游戏，其次游戏本身使用水墨风格的渲染，又加上了柔化的效果，我真不知道他们到底是受到30帧的什么影响，至少我在玩的时候并没有什么问题。

38472292.review:
Approximately 9 to 10 years ago, I purchased Okami for the Wii, its first re-release since the original on the PS2.

Frankly, I was disappointed initially. The opening sequence, including a very, very long unskippable cutscene, was extremely slow, and it felt like an endless wave of tutorial after tutorial. While the visuals were unique and attention-grabbing, it was not quite enough to sustain my interest.

I put the game down in boredom and disappointment, and did not plan to come back. But I did, months after on a slow day, and boy am I glad I did so. I trudged through the remaining slow parts of the opening, and the game steadily picked up its pace. 

I became absorbed into its massive, sprawling world beautifully designed with meticulous care to detail. The accompanying soundtrack was at times catchy and at other times emotional, but always appropriate and gorgeous in execution, defying the technical limitations of being initially developed for the PS2. Characters were humorous and filled with personality in writing and in visual design. Combat was simple but satisfying. And of course, the Celestial Brush mechanic continuously impressed in its creativity and implementation.

A few minor annoyances have not been fixed since even the PS2 days. The choppy and abrupt "voice acting" was perhaps tolerable in 2008, but not so much in 2017. Drawing with the Celestial Brush can be frustrating at times when the game simply refuses to recognize input. Some dialogue is still (seemingly arbitrarily) not skippable, leading to a feeling of being bogged down when I'm reading way ahead of the characters "speaking".

Of course, the remastered visuals haven't been a case of simply flipping a switch to change the game's native resolution. Many textures have been significantly bumped up in clarity, and many particle effects are much cleaner in appearance. The game's unique thick brush stroke outlines are sharp and defined. The end result is a game that I'd readily believe is a modern 2017 release, albeit not of the same AAA calibre as it was. New options like bringing back the PS2 loading screen minigames are also appreciated.

Special mention needs to be made about the game's controversial 30 fps lock. As someone with a 144Hz monitor and who is usually a stickler for higher framerates and refresh rates, I genuinely do not find it diminishing my experience too much thanks to the game's unique artstyle and specifically designed animations. However, it definitely was and still is a slight bummer that the now-universal 60 fps has not been implemented into this game's third re-release.

The keyboard+mouse implementation is acceptable. Some keybindings are strange (thankfully this is changeable in the menus) and the game's menus are not exactly mouse-friendly, but it wasn't too intrusive for the most part. In particular, drawing with the Celestial Brush felt extremely fast and intuitive, allowing me to draw at at a speed and accuracy far surpassing the Wiimote, much less other traditional controllers.

Do I recommend this remaster of Clover Studio's masterpiece? Unequivocally yes, especially to the folks who have not yet experienced the game in any form. Fans of the original PS2/Wii release would surely appreciate reliving the experience with vastly improved visuals and perhaps a new method of input. For the owners of the PS3 HD remaster, this is really much of the same with 4K and keyboard+mouse input, so it really boils down to a judgment call.

Visuals: 10/10
Sound: 10/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Story: 9/10
Value: 8/10
Overall: 9/10
