Okami is a game that I personally consider to be one of the greatest of all time. There is so much to Okami that to try to summarize it in one review won't do it justice. I will have to make due though.

Okami is a game depicting Japanese folklore involving the goddess Amaterasu and the legendary 8-headed snake, Orochi, and various other characters of folklore. The game puts the player as the wolf Amaterasu at the start of the game, stripped of most of her powers and immediately pits you against the forces of evil. I will say no more about the story so that you may discover it yourself; All that I will tell you is that it is a long, complex, and interesting story. To put it into perspective of how long the game is, to fully complete the game you must play it at least 2 times, once in the regular game and once in new game+. The fastest anyone has beaten the game to any % completion is 1h 22m 39s. However, the average person will beat the game sometime between 36 hours to 56 hours. So know that when you start this game, you are in for a long and arduous journey that will require investment.

Onto the actual gameplay, the game consists of semi-freeroam where you can explore and discover areas of the game that are available to you. Within these areas are story events and location-based events. Story events will only happen once and progress the game. Location-based events consist of encounters triggered by running into a cursed gate or a cursed scoll which will then trigger and enemy encounter which can either be completed or broken out of. These encounters are not like an RPG just to be clear. The combat is fluid and can become incredibly complex depending upon your knowledge of the game and weapons. Certain techniques can be used within these encounters to aid you as well.

Next, the map of Okami, while at first appearing to be large and overall not terribly overwhelming, the map eventually expands to encompass a massive amount of land covering a rather impressive amount of ground. The art style of Okami is cel-shading which gives Okami a rather unique look that further accents its beauty. You may find yourself stopping throughout the map to just look around and observe, I highly recommend you do so.

The music of Okami is yet another enchanting aspect of the game. Consisting of highs and lows, dread and happiness, drama and content, etc. The music is diverse and will be a heavy influence on your emotions and how you percieve certain situations. The music present in battles gets your blood pumping; The music present during comedical moments makes you feel jovial and silly.

Next, 100% completion, this topic of Okami is a rather involved and intricate task. In order to 100% Okami one must play the game once in 'New Game' and once in 'New Game +,' the difference is the difficulty. Next, one must find all 26 Brush Techniques (14 Regular Techniques and 12 Secret Techniques), this task will require exploration and story progression. Next one must aquire th 100 stray beads spread out throughout the game, again alot of exploration. One must complete the bestiary by discovering and defeating all the enemy types in the game. One must find all the clovers spread out throughout the map. Complete all mini-quests. Complete all offerings to the statues. Complete all Wanted Beasts lists. Collect all the artifacts. Get all karmic transformers by completing certain tasks and achieving a certain rating for sections at the end of the base game. Feed all animals within the game. Max out all stats. Find all fish within the game. Complete all races. Complete all Devil Gate challenges. And finally, max out all weapon stats using gold dust.
Obviously this will take a long time.

In Summary:

Pros:
- Amazing and breath-taking visuals and art.
- Amazing soundtrack
- High replayability
- Fluid combat system
- Long game
- Incredible story
- So so much to do

Cons:
- Heavy investment
- Possibility of confusion at certain points on what to do
- Completionist will cry
- So much to remember
- Cel-shading is not for everyone (as in I have met some people who despise cel-shading)
- The story is long and arduous, I recommend taking breaks

Shintoistyczna boginii Amaterasu, mimo że sprawnie tworzyła obrazy w stylu Suiboku-ga, to tylko mogła pozazdrościć księżniczce Kaguyi zdolności gry na koto, jak i ekranizacji "Opowieści o zbieraczu bambusu" przez studio Ghibli.
...
Że co?

Gra Okami idze drogą środka w nietypowy sposób, bo nie stara się omijać skrajności. Za to jedną skrajność kontruje jej przeciwieństwem. 
Początek gry przebiega pod znakiem minimalizmu. Jest minimalistycznie pod względem pozbawionej detali cel-shadingowej grafiki z pojedynczymi liniami gdzieś na horyzoncie symbolizującymi góry. Grafika momentami nawiązuje do monochromatycznego, tradycyjnego, japońskiego stylu malarskiego Suiboku-ga. Jest minimalistycznie pod względem ścieżki dźwiękowej - w tle słychać nienachalną muzykę wykorzystującą tradycyjne japońskie instrumenty, w tym koto - rodzaj cytry. Jest kameralnie pod względem terenu, na którym toczy się gra. Jest skromnie pod względem sterowania postacią, tak podczas podróżowania, jak i podczas walki (daleko Okami do rozbuchanego sterowania z jednej z kolejnych gier Hideki Kamyi - Bayonetcie). Jest też minimalistycznie pod względem fabuły - mamy uratować tylko małą wioskę przed potworem. 
W momencie, gdy potwór zostaje pokonany a gracz zaczyna zastanawiać się w co zacznie grać po tej krótkiej, ale sympatycznej grze, jedna z postaci mówi: "Nie możemy pozwolić, żeby ta wspaniała przygoda tak po prostu się skończyla". Zaczyna się więc kolejna przygoda. A później kolejna. I kolejna. I kolejna.
Pod koniec rozgrywki gracz przytłoczony jest rozmachem gry pod każdym względem. Projekty postaci, szczególnie przeciwników (jest kilkadziesiąt typów przeciwników), potrafią zadziwić. Wygląd niektórych lokacji, w tym dużych, dopracowanych budynków, przykuwa spojrzenie na dłużej. Akcja gry dzieje się nie tylko w całym Nipponie, ale jeszcze poza tą główną krainą gry. Ścieżka dźwiękowa okazuje się mieć ponad 200 utworów. Oprócz normalnego trybu gry, gracz w dowolnej chwili może przejść w tryb niebiańskiego pędzla. Można zebrać kilkanaście rodzajów broni, które dodatkowo można rozwinąć. Można poznać wiele technik walki. Można rozwijać postać. Eksploracja napędzana jest nie tylko fabułą, ale i sprytnie poukrywanymi, często trudno dostępnymi skarbami. Skarbów jest kilkadziesiąt rodzajów. Poza tym można karmić zwierzęta. Rozwiązywać zagadki terenowe. Spotkać księżniczkę Kaguye odnalezioną jako niemowlę w łodydze bambusu (a później obejrzeć ekranizację studia Ghibli tej legendy :) ). Pokonywać bossów. Łowić ryby. Kopać tunele. <Przeciążenie>  <Przeciążenie> Uff! No i wreszcie poskładać to wszystko w całość dzięki zakończeniu.

Na szczęście ilość idzie tu w parze z jakością. I warto dotrzeć do napisów końcowych, bo zakończenie - jako przeciwwaga do głównych, shintoistycznych, mityczno-legendarnych motywów w grze - jest kosmiczne.

Co do słabszych punktów Okami, to wydaje mi się, że twórcy z Clover Studio próbowali zrobić grę dla wszystkich - tak młodych, jak i dojrzalszych graczy. Przez to gra bywa miejscami irytująca - pewne ułatwienia, które pomagają przejść grę jednym graczom są stratą czasu dla innych np. powtarzanie tych samych treści przez NPC, tak by gracz na pewno wiedział co ma zrobić. Również walka przez to straciła i nie jest wymagająca. A zadanie z wykradnięciem ubrania Nami pominę milczeniem.
 
Okami mimo skromnych początkow okazało się wielką przygodą. Przeszło od skrajności w skrajność, zachowując w ten sposób równowagę.

40925285.review:
Okami is one of those rare few experiences in each generation that are truly special. This game is a love letter to the medium. The first thing many will notice is the striking art style—which has only become better in this HD remaster. The soundtrack will likely be the second; a mix of string instruments, Japanese flutes, piano and many more are all used together to create a soundtrack unlike any other game I've played. Each moment wouldn't be quite as tense or impactful were it not for the score.

But most surprising of all is the heavy Zelda influence woven into Okami's gameplay: The freedom of exploration, dungeons, side-quests and even the inventory all take notes from the series. But what makes Okami stand out as more than just a Zelda clone is how it uses these gameplay elements in a streamlined way to tell an engaging story. The tale of Amaterasu the sun god and Issun takes centre stage—and for most of your time; it never leaves.

In some ways this means gameplay takes a few hits: Combat can be frustrating when fighting multiple enemies, dungeons aren't as clever and a couple design flaws will become noticeable after hours of playtime. But clover studios simplified Zelda's gameplay for a reason. In the end, small issues like these aren't going to be what I remember when thinking back on this game. The fun characters, emotional story and outstanding soundtrack are what will stick by me from this journey. 

Okami isn't technically a perfect game. But it's impression will leave it as a masterpiece of storytelling for years to come.

40913012.review:
You need to buy this game. Period. That's the short review.

Beautiful, gorgeous, wonderful, amazing, and sometimes annoying are all adjectives that describe "Okami". You play as the wolf-god Amaterasu in Japan from a time long ago, destined to fight the evil Nami and bring peace to the mortal world. But - wow! - what a path you have to travel to do that, and it's a path well worth traveling.

The Sumi-e ink art style give it a look unlike any other game, while the satisfying combat and engrossing story pull you along and keep you wanting more. This is especially true later on in the game when you have to fight more difficult enemies but you come armed with the various hidden power-ups for your weapon. You'll end up looking for enemies to fight, especially once you gain the ability to pee on your enemies and drop an explosive deuce. Yes, you can actually do these things eventually.

The Celestial Brush, in which you effectively cast spells, is what really sets this game apart by giving you so many options to take down demons and interact with your world in ways that no other game can provide. Although the Celestial Brush felt far more natural with the Wiimote and the PlayStation Move controllers, I found that it translated well to a mouse. That said, sometimes it still had problems recognizing what you were trying to do. This is particularly true with the kimono design side-quest in Sei-An City where the game seems to be far more particular about what you draw.

The story is steeped in Japanese mythology and is beautiful to experience. There are lots of funny moments to be found as well as some tear-jerking moments. You might actually find yourself crying over a demonic piece of paper. No, I'm not kidding. There are a lot of beautiful details to this game and some of the characters  that you will encounter will stay with you for a long time.

WIthout question, one of the most memorable parts of the game is the music. It's a beautiful combination of modern orchestral and traditional Japanese instruments that fit the tone of the scene perfectly. When the game's soundtrack was released in Japan, it was a 5-CD set with 4 of those being music from the game. There is *that* much unique music in this game, and it's all worth listening to.

This is also one of those games that should keep the "longer play time = more value" morons happy because it's easy to get at least 25 hours out of this game. I went for 100% completion and topped 50 hours. It also throws a bit of a curve at you because when you think you're done (assuming that you haven't played it before), you realize that you still have a long way to go.

Yes, the game is locked at 30 frames per second; but if that's how you judge a game, you're an entitled idiot whose priorities are entirely in the wrong place. It's still a gorgous and fluid game with so much going for it that makes the 30 frames per second a moot point.

If there is any negative to this game, it's that the artificial speech noises can get annoying, and sometimes you have to do a lot of reading to get the full story of what's going on. For the most part you can skip past them, but sometimes the speeches drone on and on. Sometimes (okay, a lot of times) you want to smack Issun for being a mouthy smart a$$ as well.

I know that people have complained about crashes and lock-ups, but in the entire 50+ hours that I played, the game was flawless. I encountered no problems at all. (Ryzen 7 1700, 16 GB RAM, NVIDIA 970 GTX, Windows 10.)

Pros:
- Gorgeous art design
- Memorable characters
- Amazing storyline 
- Fantastic music
- Very satisfying combat
- The Celestial Brush translates well to PC
- Long play time with lots of things to do and hidden items to find
- Automatically switches between controller and keyboard/mouse
- 30 fps is still very playable and smooth while annoying the entitled, gotta-have-60-fps gamers
- Equivalent of a "New Play +" mode where you can play a new game with enemies at a higher difficulty
- You can pee on your demon enemies and drop explosive poop.  Yes. Yes, you can.

Cons:
- Some of the talking can be long and drawn out
- Does not include the gorgeous "Reset" closing credit song by Ayaka Hirahara if you don't live in Japan
- It brings out the entitled, gotta-have-60-fps gamers

The videos that Capcom uses as previews on Steam don't do the game justice. It's such an amazing game that is well worth playing, especially for $20.

40903877.review:
[quote=Walker Indica]Okami é um clássico de PS2 que não recebeu a atenção que merecia em seu lançamento, e agora está acessível em HD. Um jogo que continua incrível mesmo após tantos anos.[/quote]

[h1]História[/h1]
Riquíssima e regada de mitologia japonesa, desde a história principal até as histórias das side quests e de todos os personagens, tudo é muito bem escrito, extremamente cativante e com boas reflexões, também tem sua dose cômica para equilibrar e ser recomendável tanto para adultos como para crianças.

[h1]Gráficos[/h1]
A remasterização foi bem feita, conseguindo trazer uma maior qualidade e resolução ao jogo. O estilo da arte lembra pinturas sumi-ê. Tem uma beleza e delicadeza de encantar os olhos apesar de simples, por ser um jogo originalmente de PS2 que não teve suas artes e modelos refeitos, apenas remasterizados.

[h1]Jogabilidade[/h1]
Os controles não são difíceis de aprender e dominar. Nessa versão para computador, é possível jogar com controle e ter uma experiência mais próxima da jogabilidade original do PS2, ou jogar com mouse e teclado. Senti mais facilidade em jogar com teclado e mouse, talvez porque já estou acostumada a usar eles em outros jogos e faz muitos anos que não jogava Okami no controle (última vez foi num PS2 de amiga muitos anos atrás, antes dessa versão eu joguei no Wii mas o controle é bastante diferente). Não senti diferenças significativas da versão original, único ponto que desenhar com o pincel é muito mais rápido e preciso com o mouse.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Deixo avisado que a introdução da história do jogo é bastante longa, demorando cerca de 40 minutos até a gameplay realmente começar. E mesmo após começar, o jogo em si contém muito diálogo, muito texto e várias cutscenes. É um jogo extenso que não tem pressa em apresentar seu universo. A história principal rende fácil mais de 50 horas de gameplay, e para quem se interessar em side quests, ou conhecer mais todos os personagens secundários, ou encontrar todos os colecionáveis, atingirá por volta de 90 horas de jogatina.
O combate é bem nivelado e com boa progressão de dificuldade, e mesmo assim há como você evitar grande parte dos conflitos apenas não passando por pergaminhos demoníacos pelo mapa.
Existem diversos mini-games espalhados pelo jogo e até mesmo na tela de loading (essa é necessário ativar nas configurações do jogo). Tem diversas formas de ganhar dinheiro no jogo para comprar itens que irão ajudar a derrotar mais facilmente os inimigos ou itens necessários para avançar na história.
Uma grande parte do jogo você é livre para seguir no seu próprio ritmo, explorando cada canto do mapa, cavando tesouros, alimentando animais, fazendo side quests ou seguir a história principal, com isso é fácil de agradar diversos tipos de jogadores.
Mesmo após terminar a história principal, o jogador pode continuar jogando e explorando o mapa com todos os poderes desbloqueados, o que é necessário inclusive para encontrar todos os colecionáveis do jogo.
Por se tratar de um jogo de 2006 apenas remasterizado, o jogo tem pontos problemáticos que hoje muitas pessoas tem conhecimento. Por exemplo, o jogo contém muito fan service, com boob physics e até um personagem pervertido em suas falas e ações bastante presente pelo jogo inteiro. Pode causar incômodo em algumas pessoas, principalmente mulheres. Mas é possível apenas ignorar e focar no restante do jogo que é ótimo.
A combinação da arte característica japonesa, as referências da mitologia japonesa e a trilha sonora com instrumentos clássicos da cultura japonesa, faz o jogador ser imerso no mundo de Okami.

[h1]Conclusão[/h1]
Okami é um jogo clássico que não teve tanta atenção em seu lançamento no PS2, mas é uma joia rara que não perdeu seu encanto mesmo após tantos anos, e ainda voltou com gráficos HD para a alegria de quem já era fã do jogo e também para quem nunca jogou ter essa experiência.
Para quem joga mais no computador, compre a versão no Steam, o preço não está muito acessível então pode esperar uma promoção se precisar. Para quem joga mais em algum console que tem Okami HD disponível, compre para esse console (PS3, PS4, Xbox One ou Switch).

It's a great game and an okay port. Graphics-wise, the art syle hides the fact that it's a PS2 game and has aged pretty well in comparison to other games of it's era. It looks great, although it certainly can be better. It's still has low polygons which can't be avoided as it is a PS2 port.

Gameplay-wise, it's Okami. If you never played it before, it's action adventure game with an interesting painting mechanic you use to execute all your different skills. The combat is thus a weird hybrid of a regular hack and slash game with a combo system, though no where close to being Devil May Cry, it's even simpler than Darksiders, and the paint brush mechanic. It's a fun system, though due to the fact you can basically pause the game every time you pull out your magic brush, the game can be a bit on the easy side, especially once you get Veil of Mist and you can spam slow time all day. The game progresses similar to Zelda, you earn your new brush technique (sub weapon) which aids you in solving puzzles or defeating certain enemies and bosses that require said technique.

The down side to Okami HD? It's a 30 fps locked game on PC. No big deal, I suppose, the game isn't fast pace enough that the extra frames help you react or anything, but it is a shame. While I realise the game's physics engine is tied to FPS, given the fact that Sega and Platinum Games could port Vanquish to PC, which also had gameplay mechanics tied to frame rate and breaking their game (which they fixed pretty quickly with a patch after launch) I see no reason why they couldn't just patch out the framerate dependent game mechanics. Just seems lazy. 

Overall good game, okay port. Could be better like other publishers have proven.

总的来说，游戏很棒，十分推荐。

A beautiful, underrated game that deserves more attention. The game is incredibly beautiful with its Sumi-e ink art style which is a joy to look at. Combined with a rich traditional Japanese story, it gives an immersive and interesting adventure to experience through an open-world map inspired by the land of Nippon. Along with well-designed characters, it makes the story more interesting to look into.

For anyone who gets bored easily, this game is for you. The storyline is quite long and requires long play sessions to progress through the story. Monsters aren't too difficult with the perfect mix of strategy and pure combat. The main mechanic used in combat is the Celestial Brush.

The Celestial Brush is the main feature of the game, using 13 brush techinques to defeat your foes. The brush is easy and responsive to draw with. The techniques themselves aren't hard to draw and you will learn them quite quickly.

There are a few problems however. The game is locked at 30fps which might be a disappointment but it still runs great. There are no voice-overs for dialogue which might make the dialogue a little bland but the great storyline makes up for it. Long cutscenes are present but you can skip through them if you need to.

If you have ever played any of the Zelda games, I recommend to try out this game.

40736263.review:
Okami is definitely my favorite game. And one I'd give a 10/10 to. I played it originally on the Wii and was super excited to hear it was getting a PC port. Luckily, a friend of mine bought me the game for my birthday! The port is not the best, as sometimes I have trouble running it on max graphics, but it's still wonderful. 

The art style instantly won me over. Everything is so beautiful. Evil has taken over and cursed the lands and as you travel to different places, you get to cleanse the land of its curse and watch as it becomes enriched with nature once again. The restoration cinematics are beautiful. The characters are fun and lovable. Even Issun isn't *so* bad once you start progressing the story. 

The music is also amazing. I listen to the soundtrack so often and never get tired of it. Especially the final boss song. It's so full of hope and really makes you feel like you're playing as a goddess.

The gameplay feels nice, and I really enjoy the concept of the Celestial Brush. The game itself plays kind of like a Zelda game. There are dungeons and you get powerups (more Celestial Brush techniques/overworld techniques like a double jump) that help you progress and also help you discover new areas you could not access before. There are also tons of hidden treasures throughout the game. Most notably are 99 stray beads! If you collect them all, you get a pretty cool item that will make any New Game+ files interesting!

Combat is not particularly difficult, but it's still fun to use the Celestial Brush and figure out the best way to defeat enemies. I also enjoy the choice of using 1 of 3 types of weapons. You have your standard speed and damage Reflector, your fast speed but lower damage Rosary, or the slow speed but big damage Glaive. I personally really enjoy using the Glaives, as they dish out big damage after charging it for a second or two.

Now for some cons:
Some cutscenes, most notably the opening one, are pretty long and the text cannot be sped up. You can skip the cutscenes if you really hate them, however I think a lot of the enjoyment comes from the story. 

There are optional "trials" where you'll fight waves of enemies and I believe their health and damage have been increased by a fair amount. I think they could have made a harder difficulty of the entire game using this increased health and damage feature. It feels like a missed opportunity to me.

..And then there's the handholding. Issun, your companion throughout the game, kind of ruins all the puzzles. I understand hints are helpful for some people, but to others who like figuring things out themselves it's kind of annoying when they give them to you without you asking. I felt a little cheated when I'd figure something out but Issun just tells me right after anyway. A harder difficulty would have really made Okami shine even brighter! But that's alright. I think the other aspects of the game make up for it. 

TLDR: Okami is an enjoyable, beautiful game. The only setbacks I can think of are its lack of difficulty and long opening cutscene that will probably turn some people off to it.

TL:DR at bottom
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I bought the game for the original Wii console over a decade ago, and I have to say it was probably my favorite game on that system...and it still is.

So when I heard that they're porting the game to PC I was thrilled, but I regret that I didn't do a full research on the game before buying it.

After setting up the settings and watching the initial cutscene (oh, how memorable that was), I was astonished how poorly the game ran. I immediately enabled the Steam's FPS counter and got disappointed that the game was locked to 30 fps.
I thought that "okay, I'm a PC player, so this problem can be fixed." I started googling around a method how to unlock the 30 fps lock, but after doing so for roughly 30 minutes I found nothing. Conclusion was that you can't unlock that 30 fps lock.

After realising this I nerdraged a little bit, because who releases games on the PC with 30 fps lock on them. After calming down I double checked that is it true that you can't unlock the fps lock, but once again I found no such method. The 30 fps lock is there to stay.

The thing is that I've been a PC player for 2 decades now, so for me the difference between 30 fps and 60 fps is a clear as day and night. My eyes literally starts to hurt if I try to play any PC game that are locked to 30 fps.

So, the conlcusion: I love the game for how unique and beautiful game it is...on the Wii. On PC the game is totally unplayable for me because of that 30 fps lock. I'm still gonna try to find a way how to "fix" this problem, but if I can't I fear I'm gonna have to ask for refund. That 30 fps is just something that make the game unplayable for me.
Bear in mind that I only played the game for about 15 minutes, solely because my eyes couldn't take that 30 fps anymore.
If a PC game has hard coded 30 fps lock on them, then it's immediate no-no from me.

Thankfully I still have my trusty good old Wii system somewhere in my closet, so it doesn't matter all that much if I can't play it on the PC.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[b]TL:DR[/b]
The fps is locked to 30 and there's no way around it. Hence the negative review.

Short review:
One dimensional charachters, samey music, unintresting combat, and most of all dull story made me hate this game.

Long review:
there is so much to like about this game that is a shame that the apeal of it completely missed me.
First of all what is this game?
This is an open-world-ish game with a distinct style where you travel from scenery to scenery solving people's problems and uncover their culture.
That's awesome, so why am i not liking it?
Well the open world is to small but still managing to be tideous to traverse.
All characters (except maybe Waka) are one dimensional and keep repeating the same line over and over again.
There is this weird thing on pointing out the obvious, if a big boulder is on the road the characters would go "hey theres a big boulder on this road" and make sure everyone knows.
The story is all over the place, some things stop being important and some other come out of the blue, (you dont know who is the big bad untill the last 30 minutes of the game).
The first arc was slow and tideous, even if it had a nice closure to it.
The second arc is bad overall even going as far as retroactively ruining the conclusion of the first one, (in this for half of the time you are aimlessly wondering without any story to push you foward).
The third arc was good (even if it almost rejected all characters and enstablishment we get on the previous ones) but is only 2 - 3 hours long overall out of the 30 - 40 hours of the full game.
Combat was functional but forgettable.

So yeah, if my criticism of it didn't disuade you from liking the game's premise, well go for it you'll probably like it much more than me.

I really wish there was an inbetween rating on steam, but having to decide between a positive and negative review i have to go for a negative one.

距离第一次在PS2上接触该作已经过了12年，我终于补了一张正版的票，也拿到了全成就，这下这游戏在我心中终于是圆满了。（为了全成就我这俩礼拜连1月动画新番都放着没追！）

为第一次接触的同学们简单总结一下[spoiler]充满个人色彩的[/spoiler]优缺点：
+画面：水墨画风格+浮世绘画风（妖怪绘卷），即使是放在2018年也非常有特点！而且真的美啊！尤其是恢复神木之后的动画，此刻我只怪自己词穷啊！
+音乐：日式风格浓郁的BGM，很切合游戏的主题，有几首个人感觉相当洗脑。然后在这里墙裂推荐主题曲Reset！！绝景版的片尾通关曲并不是它，所以请一定去找来听听！真的好听！你们信我！！[spoiler]（我当年PS2通关时就是一边听着Reset一边擤鼻涕抹眼泪）[/spoiler]
+操作方式：画笔操作耶！想画小花画小花，想画月亮画月亮耶！（当年就被叫做“日版的神笔马良”呢）这种游戏方式还是相当有创意的~
+剧情：虽然故事架构用的是日本神话传说，而且还是好几个神话故事揉在一起，但在此基础上还是能看到制作方的脑洞的（比如超文明神马的，我就不剧透了）。可能有的同学觉得两者之间跳跃太大无法接受，但我觉得还好，至少我感觉故事逻辑上可以解释的通（但我也必须承认，整个故事前4/5都是和风，最后突然出现了西洋元素，还是挺……跳脱的-_-||）
+各种小细节：我跟你们讲，斯达夫的搞笑才能都体现在这些小细节里面了！梗多到数不过来！这块不多说，各位在游戏里慢慢寻找细细体会吧~
+分支任务&收集要素：很丰富，相当丰富，特别丰富。从收集珠子到喂动物再到打怪不一而足，还有赛跑、画画、钓鱼……本成就控表示一本满足。（而且很负责任地告诉你们，刨坑挖宝寻找四叶草可是会上瘾的……）
----------------------------------------------
好，下面来说说缺点：
-视角问题：有的场景下视角很别扭，虽然大部分时间视角都可以切换成俯瞰，但就是会有跑着跑着视角突然拉近的情况发生（而且还不少），比如后期和小姐姐在森林里赛跑的时候，我就因为视角的突然变换重玩了好几次_(:з」∠)_ 不说别的，突然拉近视角我会头晕恶心呀QAQ 对这方面敏感的同学最好在刚进入游戏时先把视角调整到自己的习惯状态再开始玩。
-画面模式切换到窗口后也并不能十分方便的去浏览网页或者做其他事情。而且游戏中的STEAM相应功能也并不能使用（比如想要查看成就和收藏的指南就只会出现“遇到问题无法显示”的字样，不知道这是只有我这里出现的情况还是大家都遇到了。总之我这边每次想看看珠子收集的攻略时都得退出游戏，查好了再进入游戏。次数多了会觉得有点烦）
-为什么片尾曲的Reset不见了！！！因为是绝景版么！！！（大哭）
----------------------------------------------

尽管我一直没能理解当年为啥这么棒的游戏竟然不火，但无论如何，《大神》于我而言都是非常经典的一款游戏！感谢这碗冷饭，让一直在心里惦念着它的我有了再一次重温感动的机会！希望能有更多的玩家借着这次移植STEAM的机会喜欢上它~
[spoiler]尽管是第二次玩，但到了结尾我还是哭得稀里哗啦（我泪点低，就是容易被这样的剧情感动）。只可惜绝景版的片尾不是平原绫香的Reset（听着它估计还得多哭会儿），于是我决定把MP3里的歌翻出来再循环LOOP一下。（你看我前前后后提了3次片尾曲的事儿，可见我有多怨念这一点_(:з」∠)_）[/spoiler]

Okami is a sort of action adventure game somewhat similar to zelda ocarina of time. If you are looking for a zelda fix this is the game for you. The story is a fantastic japanese mythological epic where you amaterasu has to battle the evil orochi that has poisoned the land. This is done by restoring the land to its former glory, restoring the flora and healing the land. 

The gameplay also revolves around "brush magic" where you paint your spells, this ties in well with the aesthetic brush art theme of the entire game. 

The story is semi serious yet somewhat goofy. If you are looking for some grimdark end of existence adventure...this aint for you. 

Now it is essentially solve the puzzle, collect money, slowly learn new abilities and find secret areas. my only major negative is that it holds your hand somewhat. 
"Hey, doesn't that picture look likes its missing something....?" 
On top of this the puzzles are preety easy. I haven't really got "stuck" for more than 3 minutes in this game but I am not looking for some massive time sink that I must spend hours on solving, I got a fulltime job and other stuff to do. (yet I understand its not for everyone)

That is a little frustrating but besides this the game is fantastic. Its been a long long time since a game hooked me this much. If its on sale and you are looking for your zelda fix, I recommend it thoroughly. If you are looking for some grimdark adventure, don't come here.

40497225.review:
Okami is a game I have ever dreamt of and I am happy to see it finally comes to Windows after over a decade since its initial release. 30 Fps may not good for all, but I am fine with it.    

Two features impress me -- the unique brush and the art.

Celestial Brush is the feature of the game. It is absolutely a talented idea as you can do many things as possible. The brush can be a weapon (sword or bomb), a magic spell (Lightening, Interno, Blizzard, Whirlwind or Rain) and special abilities (catwalk, vile of mist, rejuvenation,blooming, crescent and sun). Of cause, you can use them to play tricks with NPCs (Some may become angry :)). In addition, the brush can be used as signiture and will be presented after beating the game.

I love the game graphics. It presents a beautiful water-coloured world. The artworks are masterpieces. I would like to say, [i] Okami is not only a game, but also a world of art. [/i] 

Apart from the two points mentioned, there are also some easter eggs inspired by other capcom games. For example, after helping Mrs. Orange, she invites you to her home in the evening so you can have the home-made biscuits.How does she make it ? -- --Shun Goku Satsu (瞬獄殺), the super move by Akuma / Gouki in Street fighter series.

It is a legancy of Clover studio. Okami had a successful criticism however ended up with a commercial failure (original PS2 version). I do not think it is fair to the game, it does not deserve like that. There are many clovers under the ground and it is possible to digg them out. Maybe this is the most meaningful easter egg among others.

Rich storyline, beautiful soundtrack and stunning, unique art design; what more do you need?

I had the original PS2 version of this game and played the crap out of and was very pleased indeed to get hold of Okami HD. Throughout my first 65 hours of gameplay, I've only taken issue with two things; Issun has an irritating habit of continually stating the obvious - like seriously dude, shut up, I already know that - and it was only until near the end of the game that I finally discovered that 'B' is the button for walking! Why wasn't that made clear earlier? It's not even highlighted in the controls menu. 
This is a game that, in my opinion, everyone should play at least once. I defy anyone to reach the end and tell me that it doesn't make them shed a tear or two. Definitely recommended.

I remember having this game on my PS3. I was so in love, and completed the entire game quickly due to how obsessed I was.

But for a game that's over 10 years of age, It's truly stunning. Okami has beautiful artwork, filled with life, love, and despair. You don't even have to be a wolf lover to understand this game, but indeed I do enjoy how It's based off of a wolf goddess.
I'd never really been a fond of games constructed around a storyline, but Okami flows well, each event going with the next.
Though, I nearly felt like crying at a part towards the very ending. It was so inspiring, mainly because I grew attached to Amaterasu and Issun, the main characters of this phonomenal game.
You explore a world based on Japanese culture, having to constantly blow through enemies who stand in your way.



Yes indeed, it does have It's flaws, which can quickly turn obnoxious.


I recommend this game, majorly, to anyone who's willing to spend $20, as a gift or not. It's worth every single penny.

Quickly taking the spot as one of, if not my absolute favorite games of all time. 

5/8 would play again

40203060.review:
Tough decision, but ultimately I can't recommend this game at it's current technical state (as of February 18th 2018).

Okami is an action-adventure game akin to Zelda, so you can expect that the game will include exploration, puzzling, fighting, and a massive cast of characters. The main mechanic used throughout the game is what is called the Celestial Brush. You manipulate the world by pausing into a special mode and drawing different patterns with your mouse or controller. You gain more brush based skills as you venture further in the game, and these include cutting, repairing, generating vines, making the wind blow etc.

Fights usually take place in tightly spaced arenas, and you will have 1-6 enemies at a time that you will have to fight. Each enemy has it's patterns and weaknesses that you'll have to take advantage of. Boss fights will give you more space to utilize, but many of them will also need you to figure out a weakness and do a bit of leg work to get to damage the boss in the first place. Fights will net you money, which you can then use to buy supplies, weapons and new skills.

Unfortunately, plenty of people have had severe technical issues with Okami. The game is locked to 30 FPS, and yet Okami is extremely taxing on the CPU (stock Ryzen 1600X shows 60-80% usage on some logical cores). There have been reports of the game not running at all, disconnecting USB devices, to even shutting the computer down, but one of the most common issues is mouse control. Mouse movement will be choppy either from the get go or after playing a while. Camera will jitter and brush strokes will likely fail, and in a longer session the keyboard input will be affected too.

There have been no news of an official fix, and user suggested fixes are kind of Hail Marys too, some of which might require legally questionable methods.

▬▬▬▬▬ •✿• Okami •✿• ▬▬▬▬▬

• Die Grafik •
Für alle die traditionelle, japanische Brusharts mögen, ein wunderschöner Hingucker. Sei es nun beim Gameplay selbst, in Kämpfen oder lediglich beim Erkunden dieser malerischen, kleinen Welt oder die Bilder bei den Zwischensequenzen. Es ist und bleibt einfach wunderschön und atmosphärisch. Und gerade wenn man bedenkt dass das Spiel von 2006 / 2007 ist und nur in HD umgesetzt worden ist, sollte man einsehen das die Grafik dafür wirklich gut ist. 

• Story • 
Bezaubernd, spannend und emotional. Dadurch das ich das Spiel bereits auf Wii gespielt habe, war dies bereits mein zweiter Durchgang und trotzdem langweilte mich die Story kein Stück. Ganz im Gegenteil. Stattdessen war ich eher in Erinnerungen schwelgend und wieder einmal verzaubert. Die Story ist gut durchdacht und erzählt nebenbei viele Mythen aus der japanischen Welt. 

• Spielzeit •
Ich schätze wenn man sich wirklich nur um die pure Hauptstory kümmert, sollten es um die 20 - 30 Spielstunden  sein.  Wenn man allerdings wirklich die Welt erkunden möchte und auch alle Erfolge bekommen will, dann sollten es deutlich mehr sein. In meinen Fall waren es jetzt über 50 Stunden mit Hilfe eines 100% Guides. 

• Steuerung •
Ich spielte mit Tastatur und Maus und war damit auch relativ zu frieden. Die Kamerasteuerung per Maus war ab und an allerdings wirklich nervig und gewöhnungsbedürftig. Auch das Angelsystem war ein wenig komplizierter, dennoch absolut machbar sobald man sich dran gewöhnt hatte. Das Zeichnen mit der Maus lief erstaunlich gut und auch das Kampfsystem war absolut in Ordnung. 

• Fazit •
Wenn einem der Grafikstil und die japanische Mythologie interessieren, ist dies das perfekte Spiel. Preislich gesehen ist es auch absolut angemessen. Ich kann dieses Spiel nur jeden wärmstens empfehlen. ♡

新年快乐，狗年不苟。

这是神谷作品中节奏最慢热、流程最长、动作元素最轻、最重叙事的游戏，很不可思议，也很难得。假设我从未听过大神之名，有人忽悠我说这是去年的游戏，真信的，真的。

第九艺术这个概念在19世纪末被提出，然而最初抱着打造艺术之心的匠人都险些被时代的泥石流掩埋，活下来的也是举步维艰，现在我是越来越期待香草社的《十三机兵防卫圈》和吹哥的新作了。产业的成熟标志是共存，显然当年的四叶草“以艺术创作为根本”理念和行业水火不容，才落得这般唏嘘下场，让人神伤，不过一想动不动就砍头的三上、动不动的怼爆的神谷，还有稻叶敦志、桥本佑介和上田雅美这帮大佬能和和气气一起做游戏，总觉得不可思议。

“杰作，可以跨过时间。”

不仅是旺达与巨像，这句话用在大神上也是完全没有问题的。这两款游戏之所以能经过十几年时光流逝且丝毫没有褪色的痕迹，不外乎优秀的系统，而大神在我看来更加取巧，她还采用了两种古老的艺术形式：水墨画与解谜。

作为整个游戏最为抓人眼球的要素，大神的画面今天看来只能用别具一格来形容，因为这就是一幅画，只要人类还没有进化到眼睛里容不得蒙娜丽莎，你就能在PS56789+1上继续吃到卡大厨喂给你的冷饭。随着天照大神在神州平原上的脚下生花，景物慢慢渲染出来，宛如画卷打开；每当你唤醒一颗塞之芽，万物复苏，泉水流动，清风袭来和鲜花盛开的情景，这才是真真切切的“跃然纸上”啊朋友们，当然画面的逐步渲染你也可以解读为当时机能不足留下来的后遗症，没有问题。

要是以现在的标准给大神定义游戏分类，那肯定是开放世界动作冒险，但其实这就是一个完完全全的解谜游戏。解谜这种形式的游戏，早已从神话里的斯芬克斯走到了如今的电子游戏中了，科学两字在十八世纪才开始出现，在这之前人们对自然的猜想，流传下来的很多都体现在神话宗教民俗之中，猜想和认知过程就是“解谜”。其实我想说的是：解谜游戏是永不过时的。当然流程中的过多提示受到一部分玩家诟病，但毫无疑问，这些精心设计的谜题到今天也是体验优秀的。

而文化层次的话

请看https://www.g-cores.com/articles/16124

通关后想起以前打P4G真结局的时候哭得一塌糊涂，还是很吃热血漫那一套的，毕竟老套的好东西还是好东西啊。

将美术、优秀的系统、富有文化底蕴的故事完美的结合，造就了这一位“大神”，她的意义已经超脱游戏，以至于今日也没有一款与她相近的游戏。这是我心里，神谷作品里的天下第一，没有之一。

40091067.review:
This ended up being one of my favorite games of all time.

I played a portion of this game when it was on the Wii, but when it recently came to Steam I decided to go full steam ahead and finish it.  The 27 hours I spent hacking away at this game was absolutely worth it.

Gameplay:

Game play is casual and rather easy compared to a lot of other new fighting-adventure titles.  I hardly found myself frustrated when battling an enemy or a boss, but the satisfaction and flow of the mechanics makes up for its level of difficulty.  I would describe it as Legend of Zelda or Mario-esque in terms of its gameplay: very mechanic heavy and not excrutatingly hard...it's just FUN.

What's more is the game's replayablibilty factor.  You are highly encouraged to retry battles to get the best performance possible in terms of speed and not getting damaged by the enemy.  The better you do, the more money you get, the better the items, weapons and skills you can buy with Yen and Demon Fangs.

I was never bored when playing this game.  There is SO MUCH content for a 20 dollar game...and even when I want a break from the story missions it's fun to just run around at max speed through the different goregous areas in Nippon.

Art and Design:

Let's get one thing straight: The visuals in this game are BEAUTIFUL.  I have seen other reviews complaining about how it is not up to par with today's visual standards.  Well...DUH.  This isn't a complete HD makeover like Windwaker for the Wii U; it's just a PC version of the HD 'remake' from a few years back.  The game was made for the Wii and PS3 and tries its best to work with the technology it has to give a old Japanese painterly style with fluid character animation.  It my opinion, it still holds out even to this day.

If you want the game to play at its best, I would suggest simply putting the game on medium graphics with the highest resolutions.  It makes what you're looking at crystal clear and there aren't too many places in the game where it will slow down due to an overwhelming amount of textures that consoles are better suited for.

The game's soundtrack is very enjoyable to hear.  It puts so much effort in attempting to capture the feel that you are playing a game set in ancient Japan.  On top of that it changes to fit the tone of each scene very well.

Story:

Never a dull moment!  After the inital introduction, the game constantly hits you with event after event.  I found myself playing this game for it's story and being so enveloped that I didn't even know I had been playing it for 10 hours straight.

The characters and dialogue are extremely charming and relationships between the characters as well as backstories really tear at your heartstrings.  By the end of the game, I found myself loving every single character and side-character.  They even did the whole "Navi"-style side character (Issun) well enough to not be annoying but instead add a sense of wit and good comic relief to the game.

The villains in this game are also very entertaining.  The people who wrote the script really gave each villain fearsome and eloquent dialogue, even if some didn't go into too much death (for example the Lich).

Is this game worth a buy?

YES.  You're getting a fantastical and unique experience with beautiful visuals, fun and engaging gameplay, and a story so chockfull of content that it truly seems neverending until it hits its conclusion and you are left wanting more...ALL FOR JUST 20 BUCKS.  And if it goes on sale, great!  That just means it turns into even more of a special find.  I feel this game should be experienced by every gamer at least once, because it really deserves the critical acclaim it received upon its release and I haven't seen enough people talking about this game since.

Cheers!

40014193.review:
I used to love this game back on the PS2, and when I saw that it had been remastered for the PC I knew I had to get it. I'll try and give as objective a review as possible, but just know that this was a great childhood game for me so that might seep in at places.

You play as the sun goddess Amaterasu, except you're in wolf form. Darkness has overtaken the land of Nippon and it's up to you to make things right and fight back the forces of evil. However, you start the game a lot less powerful than you used to be what with people losing faith in the gods and all. Throughout the game you get back your powers and try and find the source of all the evil that is threatening to overtake the land and restore peace. 

Pros:

The game has a very beautiful art style and sometimes it's just fun to relax and look at the scenery. The HD really improves upon the art of the PS2 version (and that was pretty to begin with) and turning it up to the highest settings is a joy in and of itself. The game also runs very smoothly which I usually worry about when playing a pc port of a console game.

The story is more of a traditional good vs evil type of story with clearly defined sides, but sometimes you got to respect the villains for how well they design their plans and the heroes for how they do their best to support Amaterasu. The story has that perfect mix of dark moments, but hope that it can be overcome by good people.

The game also gives you a lot for what you pay for it. You'll be spending a good amount of time even if you only focus on the main story, and if you want to collect all the stray beads, upgrade all your powers, do all the minigames, etc. You'll be spending a while with this game trying to complete all the tasks, but it's a fun ride. 

The soundtrack is well done and perfectly matches the situation that it's being played with. I downloaded the entire soundtrack to listen to while I'm going about my day, it really is a joy to listen to.

The celestial brush is much easier to use with a mouse than my old PS2 controller and that fixed some of the old issues the console version had. 

Cons: The game isn't perfect and some flaws still remain.

The celestial brush, while much easier to work with, still has some issues. The game can have trouble figuring out which power you're trying to use depending on where you start your brush, so sometimes you have to pause for a bit to make sure you're not making a mistake. Plus, the game can get finnicky over what it considers a proper form of the lines/characters used to activate the power so ocassionally you'll be trying to draw a straight line multiple times before the game registers you want to use the power slash for example. 

The computer generated noises instead of actual voices still remain, and I still wish I could hear actual voices instead of whatever is being mumbled as you read the lines. At the very least, you can skip cutscenes instead of being stuck listening to the slow moving text. 

Difficulty: It's not a very difficult game at all. The only thing that's hard is sometimes figuring out what brush technique you need to use to win the fight. However, it's pretty easy to avoid their attacks until you figure out what you need to do. 

I didn't die at all, or even get close to a game over when playing it. It's not too big of a flaw to me, but if you're looking for a challenge then the main story doesn't give it to you. The only challenge comes when you're doing the gate trials which only seems to make the enemies have more hp and defense than make it more likely you'll die.

The hardest parts of this game can be the minigames. It's more frustrating than anything to do some of the games, especially the digging mini game as well as the Konohana shuffle one. Which has more to do with the brush powers than anything else.

Overall: The cons get a bit frustrating, but I think they're greatly dwarfed by what this game has to offer. There's a reason this game was considered one of the best games the PS2 had to offer (and that's not an easy honor to earn), and the HD remake not only does the original game justice, but I think makes it better as a whole.

40011297.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/9bjrz87]here[/url].

10/10

OKAMI is like Mary Poppins - it’s practically perfect in every way.

I think I first played OKAMI when I was 11 or 12, and I can honestly say that here has been nothing quite like it, before or since. I am thrilled to announce that it hasn’t aged a moment, and that this gem continues to shine on. I’m going to try to be as coherent and concise with this as I can, being as I’m still a little waterlogged from all the crying I did about the ending.

You play as Okami Amaterasu, the sun goddess, who has come back to life in the form of a wolf after one hundred years of dormancy. Like in all great myths, you’ve evil to defeat, lands to restore, and people to help. You can also press B to bark. The game is a love letter to Japanese folklore, and the stylization is based around sumi-e painting. It’s not just like walking around a living, breathing watercolor - you paint in it, too. The major mechanic beyond running, jumping, and fighting (and barking) is the Celestial Brush, and over the course of the game you learn different brush techniques that help you in battle and in platforming - calling vines, blooming trees, making the wind blow, calling the sun or the moon. It is truly a joy to play and its one of the games that most defly weaves together its stylization, story, and game mechanics.

Speaking of story, this game has a lot of it. Normally my playtimes can’t be trusted, but this is pure playtime - it’s not a short game. There are three distinct acts, each at least fifteen hours. The game takes you from small villages to a huge city, from mountains to plains, from the seaside to bitterly cold Northern Lands - the bredth of the game is breathtaking, and it never wears out its welcome.

Oh, christ, and I didn’t even talk about the music. The music is so good. Or the animation. The animation is so good. Or the character design. The character design is so - yeah, I think you guys get it. There is no fuller package than this.

Playing the game as an adult made me realize how much effort they put in to make this game easily playable for children - the main points of the plot, what you should be doing next, and solutions for puzzles are usually really overstated, so 11 or 12 year olds can still follow along. I don’t think it detracts from the game - in fact, I appreciate it now, and I appreciated it then - but it does break immersion a bit every time Issun, your little sprite companion, goes, “Didja hear that, Ammy?!” and restate exactly what had just been said. The main storyline isn’t too difficult to get through, but there are optional challenges and minigames that absolutely do up the difficulty - I am incredibly glad I had my more-skilled girlfriend to play with me, because she was responsible for dragging me through fights I, on my own, could never win.

Of course, there are downsides - nothing really is perfect, not even Okami. Speaking of Issun, he could sometimes be very grating - Hideki Kamiya is literally unable to make a game without objectifying women, and in a kid-friendly game that impulse is channelled through Issun. (The flipside is, though, is that sometimes I think Kamiya forgets… that Amaterasu is a girl… so when she’s oggling a character’s goofily bouncing boobies it comes off as mad gay.) Also, the game makes you fight its bosses multiple times, and that gets a little old.

Otherwise: this is a game you need to play, as relevant now as it was a decade ago. As joyous as ever. A game close to my heart. I hope, one day, it can be close to yours.

I bought this game Day 1 for the Playstation 2 when it originally came out in the United States back in September of 2006. It held my own personal title of "Best Video Game" and "Closest Thing to a Perfect Video Game Ever Created" for 11 years, until I purchased and played Persona 5 in 2017. Despite the fact that I did find a game that I like more, I still have purchased every copy of Okami ever created at least once (for myself for the Playstation 2, for my younger brother for the Wii, for myself when I got a Playstation 3, for myself for the Playstation 4, for my best friend and his wife as a housewarming gift for the Xbox One, and I also decided to pre-ordered this Steam version of the game for myself.) I think I have put a collected total of about maybe 300 hours into this game across all of my platforms, with probably half of that being from the Playstation 2 version, beaten it on five separate occasions, and still feel the need to come back for more.

Why am I telling you all of this stuff about statistics? Because I want it to be a testament to how beautiful, emotional, compelling, intricate, artistic, and amazing that this game actually is. I feel a moral compulsion to tell everyone I care for about this game, because it feels like a crime, even a relativistic sin, to not tell people about how great of a game this is. There is indeed a reason that I believed this to be the closest thing to a perfect video game for 11 years straight, and Capcom is finally doing us right by releasing it on the PC.

Get this game, you will not regret it.

*SPOILER: as a heads up, the opening cutscene takes about 18 minutes in total if you don't make any attempts to skip it, and the tutorial takes about 50 minutes to complete if you don't try to rush it. 39956006.review:
Probably the best Zelda style game not made by Nintendo, Okami takes a lot of inspiration from Ocarina of Time as well as PS2 era RGPs like Dark Chronicle and wraps everything up in Japanese folklore and one of the most striking art styles I've ever seen in gaming.

Okami frequently pops up on the 'most underrated games of all time lists', and although it not perfect, it only takes a few hours to sink into this amazing game and see why.

Its definitely not perfect, even showing some glaring flaws in areas.  It likes to waste your time by forcing you to sit through some overdrawn and sometimes boring dialogue (some text can be skipped, some can't) and silly little things like stopping the game for a cut scene EVERY time the sun rises or sets can get really annoying. Or waiting around for minutes for your inks to recharge..  Like many titles of its era, Okami's camera does its best to show the middle finger every chance it gets, especially in combat.  It also makes the platforming sections horrible, as you often die as you simply can't judge your jump correctly. 

 My biggest complant however, is that the devs chose inspiration from the worst part of Ocarina - the annoying companion.  Does anyone want pervy little bug or his cringy dialogue?  

But aide from all this, Okami is such an amazing and magical experience; it sucked me in and never let me go until the end.  The art direction is amazing, the animations, especially the wolf itself, are just fantastic, amd the explosions of color and cool little details like plants sprouting in your footsteps make this like playing an interactive Studio Ghibli film.  The music is absolutely wonderful too, and I loved using the innovative celestrial brush system for the games magic.

Like most other JRPGs, there's a main quest, lots of different side quests, and different areas of the game open up as you learn more skills and painting techniques.  I'll take you about 30 hours to get all the way through, which is perfect for the game (and Issun) not to overstay its welcome.  Even though there is combat, I found playing very relaxing, and I thought the pacing with its puzzles, platforming and fetch quests gave the game a very good yet relaxed flow.

Okami holds up rremarkably well for a 12 year old game, despite being locked at 30fps.  Aside from its flaws, it's a charming and wonderful game with a great sense of adventure, and you can feel the love and passion the developers poured into this title all the way through.  If you can get past its annoyances, this is one of the finest Zelda-likes out there. A must have for JRPG fans and something to check out of you like action JRPGs of yore like Secret of Mana or Illusion of Gaia.

Even if it is only in 30fps, I'll glady take this over another Ubisoft open world game or glitchy Battle Royal game any day of the week.

P.s Capcom, since you seem to be up for bringing your PS2 games to PC, hows about playable ports of Devil May Cry 3 and all the Onimusha games?

Trust me when I say that this game will take you on one of the wildest adventures you will ever experience.

Pros
When I heard that Okami was coming onto the PC I bought it right away, this had been the 3rd time buying it for I have a copy for 2 consoles and now the PC. And I can tell you that playing the game about 6 times now it never gets old. The characters have amazing personalities that make them so you can remember them easily. Every area you head into is memorable. The graphics themselves are amazing in every way they are colorful and fun to look at.

Did I mention how many things there are to do in this game? With feeding animals to finding all the clovers, this game can seem endless. There is a lot of backtracking the further you get into the game though but this is fine if you want to collect everything and 100% the game.

The combat is the best I've seen in a long time in video games, it's different and exciting everytime a monster is encountered or a boss is being fought.

Cons
Even after all these years of the game is first released I still have some minor problems with how some of the gameplay aspects are implemented.

Some parts of the game are overly hard and even I can struggle with them even if I've played the game 6 times now, an example being BlockHead, a "monster" you encounter multiple times through the game.

A problem that I haven't encountered but my friends have is the lack of knowing what to do sometimes, the game is vast and large so sometimes knowing what to do is difficult because of that.

The last real con I would provide is the keyboard controls. I tried them out for the first part of the gameplay and realized that using a controller is better. The keyboard is clunky and confusing, so if you do get this game I would suggest a controller.

Overall this game has aged well and I would say it is a definite pickup when you have the money to get it.

萌新入坑。40小时一周目。当初买这款游戏，不是因为信使。因为我喜欢狼（什么怪癖）。一直没时间打，刚放假，作业都没怎么动就打这个了。我确实觉得这是一款艺术品。尤其在当今这个大环境下，这样风格的游戏确实让人眼前一亮。给人的是一种精神上的震撼。（但也注定这是一碗冷饭）尤其是最后那一段，人们为天照祈祷那一段。我一大小伙子居然哭了！哭了！能够再遇到这么一碗冷饭，没有什么遗憾的。下面说一下优缺点。
水墨风，全都是！整个游戏都是水墨风！给画师加鸡腿！
主角是狼。肢体语言很丰富。看得出开发组的诚意。
音乐好棒！好棒！古风！
全是梗。一寸每次喊大神furball或者furry friend的时候我都在想象大神肯定想一口吞了一寸。还有那个成就no furball on the menu，我已经在脑补一寸的语气了。
隐藏要素好多啊。让人又爱又恨。不过也不影响游戏。
13笔业，简直是开天辟地的创新。
没有中文。半吊子英语水平，边查字典边玩，烦！尤其是这么一个以神话故事为主的游戏。
故事太冗杂。除了跑地图就是跑地图。而且英文基本看不懂，根本不明白去哪里做任务。有的连红圈都没有。游戏体验极差。八歧大蛇更是要打三遍，一样的打法！
解谜部分，全部要自己探索。就算看了攻略，也会卡关。他可能适合以前的时代，但现在都是快餐式的游戏，注定是小众游戏。
不得不说的配音，我还好，有的玩家可能不喜欢。
锁帧什么的倒是没感觉。
说了这么多，看上去减分项挺多的，但是我还是玩下来了。因为它传递的是精神上的东西。像MOBA游戏，你可以说是情怀，但更多的是社交上的功能。FPS则是奋战的刺激。如果说98买的是开发者的思想的话，那大神绝对整个剧情向我们传达的是信仰，是爱，是责任。我扮演白野威，我的感受就是白野威的感受。亲身回到一百年前，啊呀，白野威混的好惨啊。可是后面人们的祈祷，真的惊到我了。我本以为一寸是个自私的小家伙，没想到最后是他，或者说他们，拯救了世界。
这款游戏，一周目就够了。收集那么多东西太耗费时间。但是他真的值得我们花费整块时间体会一下剧情。我们的内心被各种事物占据，但我敢保证大神能给你心灵上的净化。这是在快餐式游戏占主导的大环境下，这些游戏给不了你的体验。一寸说，你一定会把这段经历说给人听的，对吧？我也如此照做了。如果你嫌98贵，去网上下盗版吧。去看一看吧，化身白野威，了解一下这段故事吧。

39765937.review:
I know i'm very late to this one, but this has probably been the best 20 bucks i've spent on games in 2017 - and will be incredibly hard to beat in 2018.
		
On the one hand this is an old-zelda style adventure game, except the combat is actually great and satisfying (albeit a bit easy), supported by a almost-Platinum-style combat-score, upgrade and equipment system. And it's all presented using one of the most gorgeous and memorable art style imaginable - which looks stunning in high resolutions - and scored by an incredible soundtrack. Load times on modern systems are basically non-existent and drawing with the mouse works flawlessly. 
		
On the other hand this is a game where you play as a dog god that constantly gets bored and falls alseep when npcs have lengthy exposition dumps, you pay 100000 yen to unlock a taunt move called "golden god" that lets you pee on enemies in combat, you become a more powerful god by feeding adorable animals or digging up giant clovers (rip Clover Studios), and generally solve everyone's problems while often letting them believe they did it themselves (which brightens their day even more). It's funny and charming and filled with likable characters, and even its mocking feels endearing instead of mean spirited. The story is engaging throughout, bringing you to a ton of unique and interesting and memorable locations, and after a few neat twists sticks the landing very nicely. 
		
Difficulty stays very managable throuhough, and the game offers a ton of safety nets on top of it, still the combat offers a lot of depth with many of the numerous enemy types having weaknesses that allow for very quick knockouts using a huge variety of weapon and brush moves and their combinations. Its skill ceiling isn't quite bayonetta or MGR, but for me personally the added drawing element with mouse support might make it my most enjoyable out of all the three.	
		
For completionists sidequesting and exploration is generally rewarded with one of 99 "bead" collectibles (+1 for finishing the game) that grant you what's basically a godmode (get it) cheat on new game+ for a fun victory lap. The optional quests and challenges are sometimes hidden behind some very obscure stuff but also contain some of the most charming and mechanically fun things to do, so i'd recommend looking up a few hints on a guide to avoid missing them before you go past the very explicitely stated point of no return. After over 50 hours my only complaint was that there wasn't more of it.

I can't remember the last time a game had a tone this joyfully wholesome and heartwarmingly charming, and i couldn't imagine a better, whimsical game to detox from 2017 (and possibly within 2018). These days a lot of games feel abrassively hostile and more and more common actively predatory towards the player - even 12 years after release Okami felt like a warm hug when you needed one the most.

PS <3 Tobi

So, I just finished this game yesterday, for the first time, after many years of hearing about how great it is and knowing nothing except that there's a wolf and you can make some stuff happen by painting.

Now? It's my second favourite game of all time.

It's been a while since I have been this impressed by the implementation of the gameplay in a game. It is INSANE how much you can do with the paintbrush mechanic alone. And it just keeps building and building on itself and keeping the game fresh after 30+ HOURS into it. I can't even imagine how much work went into that alone, designing THE ENTIRE GAME around it - levels, bosses, attacks, puzzles, the story - keeping 3D and perspective in mind, executing that must have been incredibly difficult. But that work paid off, because god damn it works flawlessly and makes the game so much fun.

However, it doesn't dwell on it, either. The gameplay merges perfectly with the story, which is fantastic, especially toward the ending. The soundtrack is equally great and complements everything aesthetically just as much as the visuals do. The art style is simply gorgeous to look at. Everything comes together in favour of the game and nothing is obscured.

It is clear as day the amount of love and talent that went into this. It is the apex of what a action/adventure with RPG elements / hack'n'slash game should be, as far as I'm concerned. I hecking loved it to bits and I really did not expect it to be THIS good.

Is it perfect? No. I do have a few nitpicks. Sometimes it's hard to tell what is a sidequest and what is the main quest, making it easy to get yourself lost and not know what to do (like in old GBA Pokemon games). But honestly, there's nothing egregiously wrong with this game and there's SO MUCH it does well it's not even worth mentioning. It is also actually pretty cheap at 20$, in my opinion. I would say it'd worth a full 60$ price easily. So do yourself a favor and play it.

9/10.

I recommend this if:

- You like God of War, Devil May Cry, Bayonetta or hack'n'slash games in general
- You like painting
- You like nature
- You like fishing
- You like dogs
- You're weeb trash who likes The Last Airbender
- You're furry trash and you want to be a dog, make people pet you, bark at them, dig holes and steal their vegetables

这是我从小到大都在惦记的游戏，小时候没钱，只能去ps2店观摩，身上的钱也不足以打通关，而且当时也没有汉化，所以当时放弃了，那时我还在上小学（现在我大二）可以说这游戏才是让我第一次真正接触到游戏这门艺术的魅力，虽然游戏那时候还是洪水猛兽，国内毫无艺术性可言，所以为了偷偷出去玩（哪怕只是待在旁边看）而没少被父母打，但我依然乐此不疲。

扯远了..说回游戏，游戏很多人都评测了，说的也很好，所以细节我就不说太多了，评论里都看得到。花98体验10年前放到现在都不过时的经典，这个价格绝对不会让你吃亏，如果你习惯了快节奏的游戏，不妨静下心尝试体验《大神》这一款游戏，与其说是游戏我现在真的很想称它为艺术品，我无法找出这游戏本身的缺点，除此之外的如果要说如没有中文，现在也有了完美汉化补丁，大家翻下最有价值的测评就能翻到，目前我看它还排在第一个，汉化基本是完美的，大家不用担心。还有是锁30帧，说实话这一点最开始的时候我也很担心，但是玩下去之后会发现30帧丝毫不会影响你体验这款游戏，可能开始会有些不适应（往往是因为习惯了60帧的游戏）所以如果你对这游戏感兴趣，又厌烦了以往游戏的风格，想换换新的口味，那么《大神》绝对是你的不二之选。

最后感谢四叶草，感谢制作《大神》的所有工作人员，以及汉化组的工作人员，谢谢你们！

如果你看到了这里，那我再说几点关于游戏的建议，如果你已经知道了请无视：
1.游戏我建议使用手柄，鼠标我觉得并不是很好操作（这点属于个人建议）
2.默认的视角操作应该会很不适应，设置里面可以更改，如果你不适应，可以在设置里把视角调整方式改为上下左右颠倒
3.不建议太快的推游戏进度，多和周围的npc对话，它们的台词都做的很用心，每个人物都有自己的灵魂，并且里面的支线同样很有意思，如果是有收集癖的人更不能错过，这个游戏需要你细心观察，并且充分发挥你的想象力，否则比较容易卡关以及错过很多有趣的东西，细细品味为佳，找到最适合自己的节奏就好，相信最后的结局一定会引发你的共鸣

随笔写的一些，如果看的有些混乱还请见谅。。。写完就准备睡了，快凌晨两点了都orz

I can say a lot of nice things about Okami. It's got charming characters, an interesting premise, and a strikingly great artstyle. I can say quite a bit of not-so-nice things, too -- unfortunately, the game is a bit too much of a cakewalk. Combat isn't challenging (nor very refined, to tell you the truth) and most of the dungeons are really straightforward. Oh, and unrelated to the difficulty itself, but I have my issues with the way the story is structured.

But for this review, I just wanted to focus on an individual aspect I believe Okami does really well: the exploration. The game is on its peak when it leaves the player to uncover its sprawling hub areas. 

As Amaterasu, the god of sun, you'll adventure through these open fields bending the nature to your will with the help of all kinds of techniques learned along the journey. You can do stuff like rejuvenating withered trees and manipulating water or wind to put out fire. Also, the earlier areas are full of obstacles that can't be overcome, since at that point you're yet to learn the required skills to solve them -- that gives you a reason to reexplore said areas later, only to find more places brimming with secrets tucked away: be it buried chests, one of the 99 Stray Beads scattered across the whole game or animals to be fed (really).

In doing these tasks, you are rewarded with treasures, consumables and experience, which aren't really needed, given the game's rather low difficulty. But you just can't help: exploring every nook and cranny of the map is just fun and that part of the experience really makes it feel like one of those great late 90s/early 00s collectathon games.

This is such an underappreciated gem of a game. While playing this old favorite, nostalgia washed over me and baptised me in happy memories and a cheerful outlook on life, which is what I truly needed right now. I think we all do anymore.

Anyways, this was a wonderful port and runs/looks fucking spectacular on my large screen. 
Using an Xbox One controller with zero issues (you're able to use the mouse for the brush strokes if you like, but the controller is perfect too). 
I saw some people complaining of the 30fps lock-but it doesn't "show" like you'd expect because of the way the art style is rendered all around you... I am usually a stickler to this kind of thing, and I can't play L.A. Noire simply because of the framerate-but again I have to stress that I didn't seem to notice whatsoever. 

I love the stories and simplicity, the depth and the comic relief throughout the narative and side quests. The mini games are fun and unique, and everything graphical is so pretty and unlike anything else I've played before or since. 

I would heartily recommend this title to my steam friends! I've had buddies pick it up and play after I describe the combat system and shinto style atmosphere--all have loved it. It's relaxing at times and keeps you on the edge of your seat at others, but I find myself playing before bed and falling asleep listening to the BGM. Great soundtrack btw. My overall rating would sit around 9.5/10~
